HEADLINE: Weighing the Risks in a Health Savings Account

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK

 BODY:
A LITTLE-NOTICED provision in the Medicare prescription drug law passed by Congress late last year is starting to shake up the group insurance market for small businesses.
 The provision created health savings accounts that allow people to set aside pretax income to pay medical bills. When linked to high-deductible insurance policies, the accounts, known as H.S.A.'s, can drastically lower an employer's costs of providing employee health benefits. This may allow more small businesses to offer such benefits -- or provide savings for those that already do. 
 Some critics argue that these plans achieve savings by shifting more health expenses to consumers, who must use the money in their savings accounts to pay their deductible amounts. The accounts, however, are tax deductible and can build each year, like individual retirement accounts; when you turn 65 and are eligible for Medicare, any money in the account is yours. The advantage of the high deductibles, proponents say, is that they keep the policies cheap. As a result, companies that offer group plans may pay some or all of the premiums and finance a portion or all of the savings accounts.
 Almost half of small businesses with 50 or fewer employees do not offer health insurance to their workers. Currently, the management consulting firm started last year by Rich Phillips, an entrepreneur in Austin, Tex., falls into that group. But Mr. Phillips said that he planned to add coverage next year for his five employees and their families, using health savings accounts.
 Mr. Phillips has purchased an individual H.S.A.-eligible policy for his family, which costs $380 a month and has an annual deductible of $3,250; a traditional policy would have run $900 to $1,100 monthly. For a single person, an H.S.A.-eligible policy can cost as little as $100 a month or less, compared with $400 or $500 for a traditional plan.
 ''I can't afford to pay $1,000 a month per employee for coverage,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''But I can afford the $300 or $400 that these H.S.A. plans cost. And it's very attractive to employees for me to pay 100 percent of the premiums for them and their families. That's rare these days.''
 ''The scary thing for a lot of people with these policies is the high deductible,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''But I see it as a great way to make me vigilant about my health costs. Plus it gives me peace of mind to know that 100 percent of my family's medical expenses above our annual deductible -- $3,250 a year -- are covered.''
 H.S.A.-eligible health insurance policies became available on Jan. 1. Because there had been a pilot program for individual policies, insurance companies offered them first. Insurers are now beginning to offer policies for the group business market that they expect will get going by early next year. ''We expect to see the bulk of this business kicking out in January 2005,'' said Andy Slavitt, the chief executive for consumer solutions at United Healthcare. 
 Individual and group H.S.A.-eligible plans work much the same way, although group savings plans may be cheaper and cannot usually deny coverage to someone because of pre-existing conditions. The plans must have a deductible of at least $1,000 to be eligible for a companion health savings account. Individuals, or the companies they work for, can make tax-free contributions to an account in any amount up to their insurance plan's deductible, but not more than $2,600 a year; families can put in up to $5,150 a year. Both of these limits are inflation-indexed and will increase. Typically, employers will pay some portion of the premium for the underlying group policy.
 If your insurance policy has a higher deductible than the annual savings limit, the difference is your responsibility. The yearly out-of-pocket maximum, however, is $5,000 for an individual and $10,000 for a family, also inflation-indexed, regardless of your plan.
 ''Ideally, the deductible on your policy would match the maximum on your H.S.A., but there could be a gap if you picked a higher deductible policy,'' said Robert Hurley, the chief operating officer for health savings accounts at eHealthInsurance.com, an online health insurance broker that is pushing H.S.A.-eligible policies. ''But since the account builds year to year, that gap will disappear. I recommend buying a policy with a deductible that matches your H.S.A., then increase the deductible -- and lower your premiums -- as your savings build.''
 In Mr. Phillips's case, he puts about $270 a month into his account, which in a year equals his policy's deductible of $3,250. After a few years, his account will probably contain more than his annual deductible. That account can continue to build, like an I.R.A. If he withdraws any of that money for something other than health care, he must pay taxes on it, plus a 10 percent penalty. At 65, he can withdraw the money without penalty but must pay taxes on it, unless he spends it for health care.
 Although the political fighting over whether to establish health savings accounts is over, the arguments provide a backdrop for the health care debate under way during this presidential election year. Republicans like the accounts as a free-market alternative to government-paid insurance, and President Bush's campaign Web site lists them as one of his major health care achievements.
 Democrats and others have argued that the tax benefits of the plans are more beneficial to higher-income people, that individual policies do not address the problems of people with pre-existing conditions who cannot get coverage and that the high deductibles may lead people to neglect routine care if they have to spend their own money on it. Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, the Democratic nominee, has proposed a variety of subsidies and other measures meant to make it easier for small businesses to provide traditional insurance. 
 For small businesses, the big attraction of these policies remains their price. They not only lower health care costs, but can also stabilize costs.
 Deena Katz, a financial adviser and the president of Evensky, Brown & Katz in Coral Gables, Fla., is switching to an H.S.A.-eligible plan for her 18 employees because her company's insurance premiums have increased 35 percent for each of the last three years.
 Ms. Katz's company covers insurance for employees only, not their families. The premiums for the coverage are currently $500 a month for each employee. Beginning in January, the company will offer health savings account policies and give each employee $300 a month. She estimates that will more than pay an individual's premium and leave some to contribute to the savings account. This $300 will, in effect, be the company's self-imposed cap on health spending. And it will save $200 a month per employee, which comes to $3,600 a month, or $43,200 a year.
 ''That's a huge amount for a small business,'' she said. ''We're not AT&T, so any dollars we can save are important.''

PERSON: Norman Frank Cantor

HEADLINE: Norman F. Cantor, 74, a Noted Medievalist

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Norman Frank Cantor, a prominent American medievalist whose books, like his classic ''Civilization of the Middle Ages,'' were widely read in the classroom and beyond, died on Saturday at his home in Miami, where he retired four years ago. He was 74 and a former resident of Greenwich Village.
 The cause was heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Cantor retired in 1999 as a professor emeritus of history, sociology and comparative literature at New York University, where he had been since 1978. Just before that he was on the faculty of the University of Illinois as vice chancellor for academic affairs.
 Mr. Cantor has won high praise for his fluent, graceful prose style and the narrative drive that made his books unusually readable.
 ''The Civilization of the Middle Ages'' has been in print ever since it was first published in 1963. It most recently came out in 1994 in a revised edition from Harper Trade, with new research focused on contemporary concerns like women's role in society and history.
 ''Inventing the Middle Ages'' (William Morrow, 1991) was a historiography documenting how present views of the period took hold.
 Another recent book in print is ''In the Wake of the Plague: The Black Death and the World It Made'' (Free Press, 2002). Its subject was the 14th-century equivalent of nuclear devastation, with a third of Europe's population killed and every aspect of its civilization upended. Mr. Cantor used case studies to illuminate the social, political and economic upheavals that reshaped views on philosophy, religion and the arts and, doing so, pointed the Continent toward its Renaissance.
 He was the editor of the Encyclopedia of the Middle Ages (Viking, 1999) and a companion volume tailored for young readers from Penguin Putnam Books. ''Inventing Norman Cantor: Memoirs of a Medievalist'' was published by the Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies in 2002.
 Mr. Cantor's latest book, published in April, was ''The Last Knight: The Twilight of the Middle Ages and the Birth of the Modern Era'' (Free Press). Just before his death, he finished ''Alexander the Great,'' a concise profile of the conqueror's life and his influence on the ancient world, which HarperCollins has on its schedule for 2005. 
 Norman Cantor was born in Winnipeg, Canada, and graduated from the University of Manitoba in 1951, the year he came to the United States. He received an M.A. degree from Princeton in 1953, spent a year as a Rhodes scholar at Oxford and got his Ph.D. in 1957 at Princeton, where he started his teaching career.
 He was at Columbia from 1960 to 1966, advancing to full professor. He then was Leff professor at Brandeis until 1970; distinguished professor at SUNY at Binghamton, and finally vice president for academic affairs, before moving to the University of Chicago in 1976.
 He joined N.Y.U. in 1978 as dean of faculty of the College of Arts and Science, a post he held until 1981.
 Dr. Cantor is survived by his wife of 47 years, Mindy; a daughter, Judy Cantor of Miami; a son, Howard, of West Glover, Vt.; and a grandson.

HEADLINE: City Center Is Offering A Smorgasbord of Dance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
City Center was where the New York City Ballet was born, in April 1948. When the company moved with the New York City Opera to Lincoln Center some two decades later, the theater's directors saved the underused hall from demolition by designating it a center for dance. That commitment has waned in recent years, but now City Center is returning the favor with a plan to provide new support for dance in hard economic times. 
 The plan maker is Arlene Shuler, a former Joffrey Ballet dancer who arrived as president of City Center in June 2003. How, Ms. Shuler pondered, could the theater be restored as a hub for dance, where major American and foreign companies perform as a matter of course to large and diverse audiences? 
 ''We already had great dance companies performing here, but we also wanted to produce something ourselves,'' Ms. Shuler said. She said she thought nostalgically of the Delacorte Dance Festival in Central Park in the 1960's and 70's, where dizzyingly different companies shared the stage each night for a heady week of free performances that drew in hard-core fans as well as people who had never even thought of attending dance. 
 Out of those memories came the idea of an affordable annual series in which dance of all kinds would be performed. The first Fall for Dance Festival opens next Tuesday for six nights with 30 companies performing, five per program, with tickets priced at $10 for any seat in the house. The $1.1 million cost of the festival was paid in part by the Peter J. Sharp Foundation, Time Warner and the Altria Group. And the gamble has paid off. Just under 6,000 tickets were sold on Sept. 10, the first day of sales. One week later, opening night was sold out and other performances averaged 90 percent. 
 For this series City Center has opened the entire 2,700-seat house, including the rarely used upper balcony. Thus small companies will have a chance to be seen by an audience far larger than in the performance spaces where they normally dance.
 Major troupes will perform, including American Ballet Theater, the companies of Merce Cunningham, Martha Graham and Paul Taylor, and the financially troubled Dance Theater of Harlem, which opens the festival with George Balanchine's ''Agon,'' performed at City Center for the first time in 1957. There will also be break dancing, Indian classical Kathak and Sufi ritual dance, flamenco, tap and trapeze acrobatics. Out of towners include the Boston Ballet and Rennie Harris Puremovement from Philadelphia. Chroniclers of recent modern-dance history will be able to compare the innovations of disparate artists like Trisha Brown, Ronald K. Brown, Bill T. Jones and Eiko and Koma. The appearances are expected to provide extra publicity for the festival companies, many of which will perform in New York at some point through next spring. 
 The lead cast of the first ''Agon'' included Arthur Mitchell, who directs the Harlem troupe. ''Fall for Dance,'' Mr. Mitchell said at the news conference announcing the series, was like coming home. Annie-B Parson, whose evocatively avant-garde Big Dance Theater is a festival participant, grew up watching City Ballet perform ''Agon.'' ''This feels like a legacy,'' Ms. Parson said. ''I'm not suggesting that any of the younger choreographers are inheritors of that incredibly brilliant work. But the fact that we're all in the same program is sort of a stroke of luck for everyone -- audiences and performers. We get to see where we've been and where we're going.'' 
 Another participant, the modern-dance choreographer Susan Marshall, talked delightedly at the press conference of at last being able to afford to see a broad spectrum of work in her field. ''I'm going to buy seats for every night,'' she said. ''I feel like a kid in a candy store. It's hard in dance to have real knowledge of what came before.
 ''Every five or six years there is a new generation of choreographers. Our foundation is continually falling away from us..''
 Ms. Shuler also envisions the festival as offering an unparalleled, affordable education for fledgling dance critics. But paramount in her mind is the building of the dance audience. A survey conducted by Dance USA, a national service organization, found that the percentage of dancegoers 18 to 24 had declined to 8.8 percent from 14.8 percent between 1992 and 2002 and that there was an 8 percent decline in dance attendance over the decade. Ticket sales plummeted after 9/11 and companies and producers report that there has been a dramatic increase in last-minute rather than advance ticket buying since the 2001 attack.
 Canny plotting has gone into luring and keeping the Fall for Dance audiences. The public atrium from West 55th to West 56th Street, to the left of City Center's main entrance, will house a festival lounge with a full bar, light food and D.J.'s from 6:30 to 11 each night for festival attenders and casual passers-by. Ticket holders will get a ''dance link'' card entitling them to discounts of 10 percent and more on tickets to dance performances at City Center and 12 other city theaters, from the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Joyce Theater to Dance Theater Workshop and Dixon Place. The discount card will also allow City Center to track audiences and venues. 
 Most of all, Fall for Dance is about those outside the curtain. ''One of the primary goals is to bring in younger people to create the next generation of dancegoers and dance lovers,'' Ms. Shuler said. ''For $10, they can afford to give dance a try, and they'll see a great night of entertainment. And it's not just young audiences we want to come but audiences new to dance.'' With five very different companies on each program, Ms. Shuler said, it is likely that there will be something each person can relate to. ''Wouldn't it be great,'' she said, ''to get them all to love dance?''

HEADLINE: Study Finds Less Youth Antidepressant Use

BYLINE: By GARDINER HARRIS

 BODY:
The number of teenagers and children being prescribed antidepressants in the United States dropped 18 percent over the last year after studies found that the medicines appeared to lead some to become suicidal, according to one provider of drug benefits.
 In a study done at the behest of The New York Times, Medco Health Solutions found that 43,859 of the roughly 3.5 million children and teenagers for whom the company provided drug benefits in July, or 1.26 percent, were prescribed antidepressants that month. That is down from 60,902 children and teenagers, or 1.69 percent of the total, who were prescribed the drugs a year earlier. It was the first decline in prescriptions for antidepressants among teenagers and children in years, the company found. 
 Some experts greeted the news with guarded optimism, saying that it meant that physicians may be using more care when prescribing the drugs to youngsters. 
 ''You would hope that the inappropriate use of these medicines has dried up a bit,'' said Dr. Richard Malone, a pediatrician in Baltimore and a member of the Food and Drug Administration's advisory committee that concluded last week that the agency should place a strong warning on the drugs about the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior in pediatric patients.
 The finding by Medco Health Solutions is at odds with information provided last week by the F.D.A. to its advisory committee. An F.D.A. official told the committee that prescriptions of antidepressants for children and teenagers continued to rise by 7 percent this year despite a growing controversy about the safety of the drugs. ''We did not see any decline,'' Michael Evans, a drug use specialist with the F.D.A.'s office of drug safety, told the committee. 
 Mr. Evans told the committee that his information came from IMS Health, a health information and consulting company. Lance Longwell, a spokesman for IMS Health, said that the company provided data to the agency, but that the agency did its own analysis. 
 IMS Health obtained most of its information about drug use by surveying pharmacies, but it did not collect patient information. Mr. Longwell said that he did not know how the agency distinguished between prescriptions given to adults and those given to teenagers and children. A spokesman for the F.D.A. said the agency would not comment.
 Medco provides prescription drug benefits for about 60 million Americans over the course of a year, or about a fourth of those who have health insurance in the United States. The company's finding on antidepressants resulted from a direct analysis of its patients' prescription drug histories, said Ann Smith, a Medco spokeswoman. 
 The Medco data suggest that the controversy about the safety of antidepressants has made an impression on physicians, young patients and their parents. Last summer, GlaxoSmithKline, the manufacturer of Paxil, and Wyeth, the maker of Effexor, both warned that studies of their drugs in youngsters indicated that some had become suicidal. For GlaxoSmithKline, the warning came from an analysis requested by the F.D.A. that looked at studies that the company had kept largely secret. None of the children in the trials committed suicide, but some thought about or attempted suicide, researchers found.
 After these findings, the F.D.A. asked manufacturers of seven other antidepressants to study the effects of their drugs on children and teenagers. Taken together, the studies found that children and teenagers given antidepressants are twice as likely to become suicidal as those given placebos. In February, the F.D.A.'s advisory committee suggested that the agency provide a general warning about the risks of suicide among antidepressants users, which the agency did in March. 
 Last week, the advisory committee voted that the drugs' warnings should be strengthened. The agency is still studying the committee's recommendation and promised to act within months.
 Dr. Lauren Marangell, an associate professor of psychiatry at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston and another member of the advisory committee, said at last week's hearing that despite the growing evidence of the risks of the drugs she was not hoping for a decline in antidepressant use among the young.
 ''I don't want to see prescriptions drop because these people need to be treated,'' Dr. Marangell said at the hearing. ''They need to be warned about the risks.''
 In an interview yesterday, Dr. Marangell said it was impossible to tell whether the decline found by Medco was real and, if so, whether it was beneficial. 
 ''It's bad news if kids that need treatment don't get it, and it's good news if people who don't need the drugs aren't getting them,'' Dr. Marangell said. Others said that the Medco data were consistent with their experience. 
 Dr. Malone, the Baltimore pediatrician, said he received two telephone calls from parents of patients he had put on antidepressants asking if it was time to end the therapy.
 ''I have 3,500 children in my practice, and to get two calls on the same issue on the same day is pretty unusual,'' he said.
 Both parents said that they were concerned about the newfound risks of the drugs, Dr. Malone said.
 James McGough, a professor of clinical psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeles, and another member of the advisory committee, said that antidepressants were often given to the wrong young patients for the wrong reasons. On the other hand, he said he saw a depressed young girl yesterday who needed antidepressant therapy. ''But her parent is so afraid of the medicines that it's getting in the way of what this girl truly needs.''

HEADLINE: Be Prepared for Anything From Pyramids to Onions

BYLINE: By Veronica Scheubel; As told to Patricia Olsen.

 BODY:
After a conference in Oaxaca, Mexico, ended four years ago, I visited the ancient ruins and pyramids of the Zapotec culture. It wasn't obvious how steep the pyramid steps were until I started ascending them. On the way down, I passed a French woman who was huffing and puffing as she climbed up. Most people are awed when they come upon this site, which is thousands of years old. I overheard this woman, who was obviously out of shape, say rather petulantly, ''Now honestly, you'd think they could have put an elevator in this pyramid.'' 
 Last February, my husband accompanied me to a soccer tournament in Tunisia that Nokia was sponsoring. One evening we went to the souk, or bazaar, to look at the wares. A young man tapped my husband on the shoulder and said that we probably didn't remember him, but he was the waiter from dinner the previous evening at our hotel, and he would be delighted to show us around the bazaar.
 Since it's an Arab country, the man talked only to my husband. I was walking two steps behind when I overheard them discussing how many camels I might be worth. The young man pointed out the sights and then took us to a factory where they wove rugs and introduced us to his ''cousins'' who owned the place. The men served us tea and showed us some of their rugs. We admired them but said we weren't interested in buying. The men kept bringing out more rugs and piling them in front of us until my husband had to tell them rather strongly that we weren't buying.
 At that point our waiter said he had to get back to work and excused himself. We realized he wasn't our waiter at all, but someone paid to lure unsuspecting tourists from the bazaar to the factory.
 At the end of a 10-day business trip in Thailand a couple of years ago, I started feeling sick on the way to the airport for the flight home, and by the time I boarded I was very ill. I spent the entire 11-hour flight lying on the floor by the emergency exit. The flight attendants gave me a blanket and pillow and kept bringing me air sickness bags. One attendant commiserated by saying, ''We've all had it happen.''
 You meet all kinds in airplanes. Like the seatmate I had on a flight from Paris to New York who was a dead ringer for Woody Allen and who ate onions throughout the trip as though they were apples. His breath prohibited extended conversation.
 Or like the woman in her 30's on a flight I was on from Frankfurt to the United States in March who fled economy class to business class because she didn't want to sit next to a dark-skinned man with a winter scarf tied around his head like a turban. When the flight attendant ordered her back to her seat, she burst into tears and begged to be allowed to stay where she was because she was afraid the man might belong to Osama bin Laden's group. The flight attendant asked if anyone else would volunteer to switch seats with her but got no takers, and so sent her back to her fate.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Chief Sees Potential Hazard in U.S. Fiscal Policies

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

 BODY:
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Rodrigo de Rato, said yesterday that the dollar would have to fall and the United States would have to tackle its growing indebtedness to avoid a threat to the world economy some time in the future. 
 In an address at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, Mr. de Rato did not spare rich or poor nations in his diagnosis of the world economy and said it was a good time for all countries to begin cutting their deficits and making needed changes.
 He noted that with the United States' deficit remaining well over 4 percent of its gross domestic product for years to come, ''some correction in the value of currencies will make sense from the point of view of fundamentals.'' 
 ''We believe such a large imbalance is a risk not only for the United States economy, but for the world economy,'' he said. 
 Fortunately, with the global economy in a growth spurt, developing nations can put in place needed changes and wealthy nations can begin to balance their books, he said. The United States should begin cutting its budget deficit, projected at $420 billion this year, as well as its current account deficit, which hit a record $166.2 billion in the last quarter. 
 Taken together, economists warn, these deficits could set off a sudden fall in the dollar and reverse the global recovery, though others disagree, saying that the two factors will instead quietly erode American dominance of the world economy.
 The United States was not the only wealthy country to be singled out for the threat it posed to the global economy. 
 In his speech made in advance of next week's annual meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, Mr. de Rato said that Europe and Japan also shared some of the responsibility for the United States' deficit because of their failure to expand their sluggish economies fast enough. 
 He said that ''the lack of growth in Europe means greater pressure on the U.S. domestic market'' to bear the burden for the recovery and that although Japan's economy was now much better than in the last decade it still '' has to play its role.''
 Many economists, however, cite the overvaluation of the dollar in international currency markets, especially in relation to China and Japan, as a reason for the growing United States deficit. 
 Mr. de Rato said yesterday that he had told the Chinese government that it should move to a more flexible exchange rate ''right now.''
 Answering critics who have charged that the I.M.F. has abandoned its role of monitoring global exchange rates, Mr. de Rato said it was noteworthy that his first visit after being named managing director this year was to Asia, specifically to Japan and China. 
 American manufacturers and labor unions recently petitioned the Bush administration to sue China at the World Trade Organization for keeping the value of its currency fixed against the dollar. 
 They said they had asked for this unorthodox remedy because they had lost faith that the I.M.F., which normally handles international disputes on currency, would ever persuade China to increase the value of its currency.
 The administration denied the petition.
 In the view of many economists, a Chinese move toward a more flexible exchange rate would increase the value of the Chinese currency against the dollar and relieve some of the pressure on the United States trade deficit.
 Mr. de Rato, the former Spanish finance minister who is credited with the expansion of that economy, said that developing countries needed to improve their domestic policies and practice good governance if they were to benefit from programs to relieve their indebtedness.
 He also said, however, that forgiving the debts of these poor nations was not enough; that wealthy countries needed to increase foreign aid and open their markets to greater trade if developing nations were to sustain their growth. 
 Mr. de Rato promised to speak up about problems before they wreak havoc in the world economy. 
 ''We need to identify imbalances and vulnerabilities to allow for corrections before they can create harm,'' Mr. de Rato said. ''And, we need to communicate our positions clearer, both to policy makers and to markets, and reinforce incentives for countries to undertake pre-emptive corrective actions.''
 At the same time, Mr. de Rato acknowledged that his influence over these economic powerhouses was largely through markets and public opinion.

HEADLINE: Ex-General Appears to Win By Big Margin in Indonesia

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
A former general who has promised to uphold civilian rule appears to have easily defeated President Megawati Sukarnoputri in Indonesia's presidential election on Monday, a nationwide sampling of votes indicates.
 Gen. Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono is expected to win 61 percent of the vote, compared with 39 percent for Mrs. Megawati in the runoff election, according to the survey by the Washington-based National Democratic Institute. 
 ''There could be a shift of a couple of percentage points, but the count is pretty stable,'' said Paul Rowland, the executive director of the institute here in Indonesia. The survey, called a quick count, is based on votes cast at 2,000 polling places throughout the nation. 
 General Yudhoyono, 55, would become Indonesia's sixth president since independence in 1945, and the fourth since the fall of the authoritarian leader Gen. Suharto in 1998. 
 The Monday voting, which proceeded in a well organized and peaceful manner, was the final round in the first direct balloting for president in Indonesia.
 The results indicate that Indonesians are yearning for change after three years of lackluster leadership from Mrs. Megawati, who presided over an anemic economy and during whose term a homegrown radical Islamic group carried out three terror attacks. 
 General Yudhoyono presented himself as a man of competence who could set things right, though he gave few details of precisely what he would do. He pledged to continue the civilian rule that was established after General Suharto's ouster, and was viewed as more of a reformer than Mrs. Megawati, who largely practiced status quo politics. 
 The Bush administration -- particularly Assistant Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, who was ambassador to Indonesia in the late 1980's -- has said the success of elections here in the world's most populous Muslim country shows that Islam and democracy are compatible.
 During the Suharto era, General Yudhoyono was sent to the United States twice for military training, and American officials said they hoped that lessons he had learned there would infuse his administration.
 The United States did not publicly express its preference in the election, but Washington officials made it clear that they believed that the general had a better grasp of how to control Jemaah Islamiyah, the radical Islamic group held responsible for the three terror attacks.
 During the campaign, General Yudhoyono suggested that he would curb rampant corruption, create jobs and improve security. But his precise plans remain unclear. Those who know him describe him as cautious. ''He's a cautious reformer,'' said Harold Crouch, an Australian expert on the Indonesian military. 
 An estimated 150 million Indonesians were registered to vote. Thousands of domestic and foreign observers watched the voting, from Aceh in the northwest to Papua in the east.
 They reported few disruptions, though General Yudhoyono's camp said it would be especially watchful for possible fraud as the ballot boxes were moved from the polling places to collection points at subdistricts. 
 But as counting proceeded late Monday night, General Yudhoyono said: ''It is time for reconciliation. I acknowledged during this competition that there is distance between the supporters of Megawati and myself. I expect we have to be more united in the near future to face a national challenge of building a better Indonesia.''
 Here in Jakarta, much of the voting was completed by 11 a.m. Polls closed at 1 p.m., and less than an hour later the results were known at some polling places. 
 At one voting place in Kebonkacang, a working-class area in the city center, General Yudhoyono received 137 votes and Mrs. Megawati 39. 
 Those who voted for Ms. Megawati seemed conciliatory. ''I hope S.B.Y. will fulfill his promise to the people,'' said Ceisar Saragih, 27, referring to the former general by his initials, as many people here do. ''I hope he does not pressure people with his military stick.'' 
 Another Megawati voter, Joni Tampubolon, 53, said he worried that General Yudhoyono might bring back military rule. ''We're still learning democracy,'' he said. ''As long as he continues democracy and is not like Suharto, it's O.K.'' 
 The Indonesian Election Commission trained hundreds of thousands of election workers to staff the polling places, and the political campaigns trained observers to watch out for their interests as voting got under way. 
 For many of the election day workers, helping to give voters the ballots and ticking off names on the register proved a rewarding way to promote the new democracy. 
 ''I have to be involved,'' said Rudi Halim, 25, who usually works with his father at the family store but this morning was wearing the bright orange vest of an election worker. ''It's an obligation of being a citizen.'' 
 General Yudhoyono won a first round of the election on July 5. But he failed to win the more than 50 percent required for a first-round victory against Mrs. Megawati and three other candidates. His strong showing in the runoff will probably lead to a change in Indonesian politics.
 The general's political rise was swift. He was the security minister in Mrs. Megawati's cabinet, and left only in March. His entrance into the presidential race was predicated on the sense that he did not need a major political party to support him. 
 He was backed only by a small new party, the Democratic Party, and his gamble worked.
 One outcome of his victory is likely to be a housecleaning of Golkar, the party that Suharto created in the 1960's and developed into the political machine that kept him in power.
 The leader of Golkar, Akbar Tanjung, decided to back Mrs. Megawati against the wishes of his rank and file. Golkar handily won parliamentary elections in April, though, and General Yudhoyono will have to work with the party to get his programs through the legislature. 
 In a Golkar stronghold in the southern area of the province of Sulawesi, the party fared exceptionally badly. Instead of choosing Golkar, voters overwhelmingly voted for General Yudhoyono and his running mate, Jusuf Kalla, who comes from that region.
 An election observer, Smita Notosusanto, who is also the executive director of the Center for Electoral Reform, said that in some voting places in southern Sulawesi 98 percent of the vote had gone to the Yudhoyono-Kalla ticket.
 ''It shows that Golkar is factionalized, divided and no longer the machine that matters,'' Ms. Notosusanto said.

An article yesterday about the presidential election in Indonesia misstated the current position of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Bush administration official who was ambassador there in the late 1980's and has said that the voting, in the world's most populous Muslim country, shows that Islam and democracy are compatible. He is deputy defense secretary, not assistant secretary.

HEADLINE: Looking for a Chance by Looking for Trouble

BYLINE: By KAREN ALEXANDER

 BODY:
MAKE trouble your ally. That's the advice experts have for would-be entrepreneurs. Turmoil -- economic or social -- creates opportunity, even as it pushes managers and other employees out of their corporate niches.
 From such upheaval come new demands for services -- from overloaded working people, from bricks-and-mortar companies grappling with the information age.
 Banks merge, putting midlevel executives out of work; some of them are starting small, community-based banks. Baby boomers are striving to deal with their parents' needs; small businesses are springing up to provide older Americans with companions and to plan their care. 
 And then there's dirt.
 Consider the Molly Maid cleaning company, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., which has 311 franchises in the United States.
 As families take on multiple jobs to make ends meet, they need help at home. ''The industry is really in its infancy right now,'' said Perry D. Phillips Jr., the founder of the Association of Residential Cleaning Professionals, a year-old trade association in Meridian, Miss. The home cleaning business generates $20 billion in annual sales, according to industry analysts, and demand is expected to rise 7 percent a year for the next two years. Owning a low-tech, labor-intensive cleaning franchise may not evoke the glamour of 90's-era dot-com entrepreneurialism. But with a relatively low cost of entry -- about $100,000 -- it might be just the place to stake a claim in the evolving service economy.
 The typical new franchisee is someone who got ''caught in some downsizing wave'' and is looking for independence, said Robert Goggins, the director of franchise development for Molly Maid, a subsidiary of Service Brands International. ''I've never sold a franchise to anybody that was in the cleaning business before.''
 The company requires franchisees to have $30,000 in liquid funds and a net worth of $250,000, Mr. Goggins said. Molly Maid franchisees can expect to earn profits of about 18 percent of their revenue, owners said, with top owners doing more than $1 million a year in sales.
 George Solomon, a deputy associate administrator at the Small Business Administration, pointed to two basic trends opening up such opportunities. ''The secret of going into business in the next 10 years will be finding ventures that either provide customers with information or save them time,'' he said. 
 He offered a prime example of a business that does both, in an arena that has undergone extreme consolidation and a crisis of confidence.
 ''The financial planner is going to be the insurance agent of the 21st century,'' said Mr. Solomon, who is also an associate professor of small business and entrepreneurship at George Washington University. He sees a growing demand for businesses that ''talk total financial packages, including life insurance, retirement plans and estate planning.''
 Delia Fernandez, 52, became a financial adviser in Los Alamitos, Calif., 10 years ago after losing her public relations job. ''When in doubt, retool,'' Ms. Fernandez said. She already held an M.B.A., and had previously worked at a credit-reporting bureau, where she had realized that she had a passion for talking with people about their money.
 So she went back to school and earned a certificate in personal financial planning in 14 months, which she estimated cost her about $5,000 in addition to the cost of software and subscriptions to financial services.
 Ms. Fernandez provides individual planning and asset management, and said her clients were largely middle-class ''people who still work for a living.'' She charges $200 an hour for face-to-face time, and earns about 1 percent annually from the accounts she manages. She now manages about $15 million. 
 ''You have to assume you're going to have to feed yourself for three to five years,'' she said. ''And it will take maybe five to seven years before you are going to start making money, start feeling comfortable.''
 A growing cadre of laid-off bankers have taken entrepreneurship a step further: starting community banks, particularly in smaller towns in the South and the Midwest.
 ''There's always a place for a local well-run community bank,'' said Bruce Plummer, a former consultant for start-up banks who went on to help start one himself. Mr. Plummer, now vice president of marketing and business development for MidSouth Bank in Murfreesboro, Tenn., said community banks were nimble and personal and strike a chord with homeowners and small-business owners.
 The bank, which opened in January in a former church, raised $30 million in start-up capital from individual investors who paid $10 a share. In its first 100 days its assets reached $50 million, according to Mr. Plummer.
 Just as the financial landscape is changing, so are the technological opportunities. While the dot-com bubble may have burst, there are intriguing developments in what, again, may seem like less glamorous fields. 
 ''There is a lot of focus on how to do things creatively in supply-chain logistics and transportation,'' said John A. Challenger, the chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., an outplacement company in Chicago.
 ''Companies are fighting to move more and more of their material out of the warehouse,'' Mr. Challenger said. ''Their real warehouse is the truckloads of goods that are out on the roads.''
 Some of those trucks belong to Spartan Warehousing Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, which has transformed itself into a full-service logistics company, said Steve Harmon, the chief financial officer.
 Companies are increasingly eager to find others to do the distribution work they used to do for themselves, said Mr. Harmon, whose father, Ed, founded the business in 1988. Today, Spartan Warehousing has $15 million in annual revenue, employs about 130 people and has about 2 million square feet of warehouse space in Ohio and Indiana.
 ''Everything that's imported gets shipped into the U.S. one way and delivered to the buyer a different way,'' Mr. Harmon said.
 Farming out distribution work helps companies that are conservative about putting people on their payroll and investing in mortar and brick, Mr. Harmon said. This is especially true, he added, ''if they know their demands are seasonal, or if they know they can't build a warehouse, or don't want the liability for the property on their balance sheets.''
 What has been driving the logistics business for the last five years is technology, Mr. Harmon said. ''Without it you can't provide value-added service in this industry. Everybody wants to be bar-coded.''
 He added that clients also wanted global positioning systems on the trucks and predicted that the industry would soon be moving toward radio frequency identification, using electronic chips that can both identify and track single items.
 Other kinds of long-distance support -- for aging parents, for example -- demand the ultimate in hands-on care. Structural changes in the economy mean that people ''don't have time or don't live in the same city as their aging parents,'' said Steven Aldrich, a manager who tracks small-business trends for Intuit, a software company in Mountain View, Calif., that markets accounting and managerial software for small business.
 As a result, Mr. Aldrich said, the business of ''companionship'' for elderly people is booming, whether that means round-the-clock home health aides or just helping an elderly person run errands or get to doctors.
 The Department of Labor projects the number of home health aides will increase to 859,000 in 2012 from 580,000 in 2002. 
 Rona Bartelstone, a licensed social worker, was a pioneer when she founded her elder care management company 21 years ago in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. In addition to providing private in-home health care assistance, she was one of the first to offer private geriatric care management, which includes assessing the needs of the older client and family, making recommendations for care and being an advocate for the client in the health care system. 
 Today, her company, Rona Bartelstone Associates, has 160 employees and earns more than $4 million in annual revenue. For the vast majority of her clients, their support system is over a long distance.
 ''They hire us because they can't come back every time there's a crisis,'' Ms. Bartelstone said.
 There are also dozens of Web sites like ElderLifePlanning.com, where professionals offer advice on topics like legal issues, finding appropriate nursing care and financing the costs of caring for aging family members. 
 Baby boomers have their own approach to health care, which is opening up new opportunities. At a time of soaring medical costs, a recent study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that 36 percent of adults in the United States had used some form of alternative medicine in the past year. 
 Emily Montes, 29, is hoping that trend will produce a successful acupuncture practice in Southern California. Ms. Montes, a massage therapist at a day spa in Santa Monica, Calif., for the last four years, recently took her state board exams in acupuncture.
 The acupuncture and Oriental medicine business is growing ''exponentially,'' said Debra Persinger, chief executive of the National Certification Commission for Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine, in Alexandria, Va., which administers proficiency exams. 
 Ms. Montes estimates that her education cost about $30,000. She expects the investment to pay off because ''you can feasibly work eight hours a day as an acupuncturist and see three patients in an hour.'' Ms. Montes expects to charge $80 per treatment. 
 Of course, once a would-be small-business owner finds a vein of opportunity, the real work has just begun. Charita Bullard, 47, says she is putting in about 60 hours a week operating the Molly Maid franchise she owns in Tallahassee, Fla. Ms. Bullard is currently adding her fourth two-person cleaning team and spends roughly $4,000 a month in advertising because her franchise is in a region without previous exposure to the Molly Maid name. 
 ''The easiest part for us was getting customers,'' Ms. Bullard said. ''The hardest part for us was finding employees who wanted to be committed to quality.'' 
 ''We've grown rapidly,'' Ms. Bullard added. ''I want to maintain the quality as I grow so I don't implode in 10 months.''

HEADLINE: KB Home Earnings Up

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
KB Home, a builder of new homes, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 20 percent, driven by a greater number of homes sold and higher margins. 
 KB said net income rose to $117.9 million, or $2.84 a share, from $97.8 million, or $2.33 a share, a year earlier. 
Revenue in the period, which ended Aug. 31 and was the third quarter of KB's fiscal year, increased 21 percent, to $1.75 billion from $1.44 billion, short of the $1.85 billion that six analysts had predicted. Sales of new homes rose 24 percent, to $1.72 billion from $1.39 billion. 
 Analysts on average had expected the company to post earnings of $2.73 a share.
 KB Home builds chiefly moderately priced homes in the Western, Southwestern, Southeastern and Great Lakes regions of the United States.
 Net new orders during the quarter increased 23 percent, to 8,982 from 7,319. These orders are not part of the quarterly revenue figures because builders do not record home sales as revenue until closing. 
 KB said it ended the quarter with a backlog of 21,928 homes on order and awaiting construction, up 32 percent over last year.

HEADLINE: If Failure Is Normal, How Do Workers Fare?

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO

 BODY:
MATTHEW GERSHNER, a salesman from Manhattan, remembers gauging the declining fortunes of a past employer by the location of its annual sales meeting. ''One year it was held in Atlantic City at a nice hotel,'' he said. ''The following year it was at a lodge in the Catskills, and the year after that, conference calls.''
 There were other signs that the small technology company, where he worked for four years, was in trouble. Managers suspended matching contributions to the 401(k) plan, he said, and they were reluctant to replace outdated equipment. 
 ''They didn't tell us much, but we knew things were tenuous,'' said Mr. Gershner, 31, who was one of 180 employees out of work after the company shut down in 2002.
 Even so, Mr. Gershner says he prefers working at small companies, like the language-translation services business where he is now employed. ''At the end of the day, I feel like I've added to the bottom line in a very measurable, substantive way,'' he said.
 But while there are many attractions to working at a small company, job security is not necessarily among them. Only about half of new companies survive at least four years, according to the Small Business Administration. Last year, 584,800 businesses closed shop, compared with 572,900 that started up, it said.
 ''Small businesses are more vulnerable,'' especially to economic changes, said John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement company in Chicago. ''Bigger businesses usually have built in, through a broader product mix, an insulation that small businesses just don't have.''
 And if the bottom drops out, workers for defunct small businesses may find themselves with unpaid wages and fewer protections than workers for big failed companies. 
 So how can people in small companies protect themselves?
 The overriding advice from employment experts is to be cognizant of any problems brewing and to take appropriate action before things go awry. ''In a small business, you can really see up front what's going on in a way that larger businesses can disguise,'' Mr. Challenger said. ''You may overhear a telephone conversation or see the anxiety in the owners' faces.'' 
 Often there is not much you can do. ''You can sue if you're owed money, but if they closed up shop, you don't know how far you'd get,'' said Amy DelPo, an employment lawyer in San Francisco and co-author of ''Everyday Employment Law: The Basics.'' Employment contracts won't help, either, experts say. 
 Then there are problems that can arise whether the business stays afloat or not. Ms. DelPo said that in some cases, small-business employees might not even be covered under certain federal employment laws, especially if a company has only a few employees. The Family and Medical Leave Act, for example, kicks in only if a company has more than 50 employees; the Age Discrimination in Employment Act applies to employers with 20 or more employees. But she and others suggest that workers find out if laws in their states provide protections. 
 One source is Workplace Fairness, a nonprofit organization affiliated with the National Employment Lawyers Association. Its Web site, workplacefairness.org, provides information on workers' rights, including state laws. The association, at nela.org, has information on labor issues and a database of lawyers. 
 People who work in the so-called underground economy are especially vulnerable. ''A lot of people in this country get paid under the table,'' Ms. DelPo said. ''They don't think it's a big deal, but what happens if they get injured or laid off? They're often not entitled to unemployment or workers' compensation because they haven't been paying into the system.'' 
 The warning signs that a company is in trouble will vary. They may be subtle, like workers making do with older equipment, as was the case with Mr. Gershner, or more blatant, with layoffs announced.
 Jonathan Oleinick, 32, of Miami, recalls being told by the small media company where he was employed to cut back on business lunches and, eventually, professional conferences. By the time the company had laid off about 20 percent of its work force, Mr. Oleinick was out the door. He now runs a small energy company developing solar panels. 
 Mr. Oleinick seems to have known when to get out. But why guess? ''Approach your boss -- try to ask at the highest level -- about what's really going on,'' said Robert S. Levin, editor of The New York Enterprise Report, a publication about small businesses. ''You might want to ask what are the cash-flow projections; most companies have difficulties with cash flow, not profitability.'' 
 The next step, he said, should be to ask how you can help. ''Is the ship sunk or is it just a difficult period that can be fixed?'' Either way, Mr. Levin says, you should start conserving cash, and seek out other job opportunities through networking.
 Arnold H. Pedowitz, an employment lawyer in Manhattan, agrees, but also cautioned against disclosing too much information about a company's financial status to outsiders, especially those in the same industry. ''There's a duty of loyalty that you act in the best interest of your current employer,'' he said, adding that employees who breach that ''duty'' can face legal problems. 
 But knowing where to draw the line is important. ''It's perhaps the biggest peril of working for a small business,'' Mr. Pedowitz said. ''You become involved in feeling loyal to a company, and as it's going downhill, you sacrifice what's owed to you.''

HEADLINE: Portraits From North Main Street, the Heart of a Town

BYLINE: By JO NAPOLITANO

DATELINE: ALTAMONT, Ill. 

 BODY:
THE shorthand term for small business in economic debates is Main Street, and the sector has long been mythologized as the all-American heart of small towns and cities across the country. And, in fact, North Main Street here is the home primarily of small storefront shops and companies. 
 The streets are quiet and business is often less than booming in this city of about 2,200 in central Illinois, but the small-business owners are determined to persevere. They patronize one another's businesses, turn their collective nose up at the big-box retailers that have set up just outside city limits and although the future may be uncertain, one thing is sure: they won't go quietly. So they busy themselves with plans of expansion, smile at their customers to win some loyalty and hope for the best. JO NAPOLITANO

1. GERALD WHITE Jr.
S&W Supermarket
23 North Main Street
 Mr. White, secretary-treasurer of S&W Supermarket, says the company struggles every day to overcome the low prices offered by the handful of big stores that surround Altamont. So far, his attention to customer service seems to be working. The supermarket, which has been in business since 1978, moved to this location three years ago and nearly doubled in size to 8,500 square feet. 
The store has approximately 35 employees; about 15 are full time.
 The S&W, known locally for its high-quality meats, is determined to hold on to its niche; knowing that though its prices may be similar and in some cases slightly higher than in the Wal-Marts and Kmarts that surround them, it stresses service. The store, in addition to carrying out the grocery bags of all of its customers, also delivers free to their homes. Shoppers over 60 get 10 percent off on Tuesdays.
 ''We have competition on all sides of us,'' Mr. White said. ''We have a huge debt load because of our expansion a couple of years ago. But the wolf hasn't gotten in the door yet. Our bank is very pleased with us.'' 

2. DANIEL A. LUTZ
State Farm Agent
9 North Main Street
 Mr. Lutz, 58, has been a State Farm agent for 28 years and currently serves more than 600 households. He has one employee, his secretary, Brenda Hofmann. 
 ''When I started, I had a rate book, pen and calculator,'' he said. ''Now you hit a button, the application goes down to Bloomington, and it's all done a lot faster and with fewer people.'' 
Mr. Lutz, a former teacher and high school principal, left education decades ago for what he says was a more tranquil professional life.
Business has been good, he said. He has insured some of the same customers for decades, watching their needs change as they grow older. The same children that walked by his storefront when he first started are now having children of their own, and Mr. Lutz is writing insurance policies for some of them.

3. WILEY GALLOWAY
Galloway's Barbershop
5 North Main Street
 Mr. Galloway, 90, has been cutting hair since the Calvin Coolidge administration. He started trimming his siblings' hair when he was 10 and eventually offered free haircuts to all the children in his neighborhood. 
Mr. Galloway, the lone barber in the shop, revels in the time he spends with customers, sharing jokes and occasionally playing his violin in impromptu solo concerts inside his storefront business. A self-taught musician who gently taps his right foot to keep time, he is well known and beloved.
The shop invokes an older era with wooden clocks, yellowing newspaper clippings and Norman Rockwell prints nearly covering its walls. As part of the ambience, an old advertisement reads, Shave & Haircut, 2 bits. Mr. Galloway charges slightly more: $6 a cut and $2 for a shave. He serves roughly six to eight customers each day and takes just three days off each month.
Mr. Galloway, an active and jovial man who has outlived many of his clients, is also a favorite among locals for the many stories he tells. The shop will most likely close when Mr. Galloway calls it a day.
''I think my legs will tell me when to quit,'' he said.

4. CONNIE SEIDEL
Piece-Able Kingdom Antiques
3 North Main Street
 Ms. Seidel opened her store on Sept. 28, 2002. An avid collector who went antiquing with her parents as a child, she had long dreamed of opening a shop of her own, a place where she could sell some of the many items she had collected throughout her adulthood. 
Ms. Seidel, whose 25-year-old daughter, Faye, helped set up the store in a grocery that had closed, said she has almost doubled her original space and sells the wares of about 10 vendors who rent space inside the store.
 Ms. Seidel has just two employees, a store manager, Lynn Nieman, and a part-time sales assistant, Dorothy Bush. Business, she said, is good, in that she has no debt. 
''Right now, we are even,'' Ms. Seidel said. ''I have not had to borrow any money, but I'm not seeing a big profit. I haven't had to put anything on credit. Everything is bought and paid for month to month.''

HEADLINE: United to Offer a Premium Service on Some Transcontinental Flights

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey. 
On the Road appears each Tuesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
Not much makes sense these days in an industry that has lost more than $20 billion while cutting prices sharply as demand increases. So let's not automatically scoff at this bright idea from United, a bankrupt airline that is ready to start up a fancy new transcontinental service to lure high-paying premium business fliers who will pay top dollar for flat-bed seats and other frills.
 This move comes amid fierce price competition on transcontinental routes. Yesterday, for example, I flew on Continental from Newark to Seattle. My round-trip coach ticket was $296.70, and it wasn't a promotional fare, just one booked routinely online. Plus, because I fly enough miles on Continental each year to maintain Platinum Elite status, I was upgraded to first class each way. So we're talking about a round-trip fare to Seattle, in first class, of under $300. 
 Surely, then, United has to be kidding when it says it expects to make money selling new premium-class service between New York and Los Angeles and New York and San Francisco, with round-trip fares of $2,800 in first class, $1,500 to $1,800 in business class and $200 to $1,000 in what it calls ''economy plus.''
 It's an idea that's going to fly, says Martin C. White, United's senior vice president for marketing. Despite the proliferation of cheap fares to the West Coast, there is, he insists, a viable premium market on the most-prized transcontinental routes out of Kennedy Airport. Right now, American Airlines has half of that premium market (the first and business-class fares), and United has 37 percent. So starting next month, United, a unit of UAL, is introducing new service -- ''p.s.'' (for premium service) -- on those routes. The 767-200 United aircraft currently flying those routes will be replaced by newly configured 757's.
 ''The idea on these routes is to not fight on a share basis, but on a product basis,'' Mr. White said. This means appealing to what he said was a significant niche of well-heeled business travelers, the core of them flying out of Kennedy Airport and Los Angeles International, who are willing to pay more for a certain level of premium service they cannot currently get on domestic flights, he said.
 On those routes, ''when you look at where the money is made, more than half of the revenue in those segments come from first and business class,'' he said.
 Essentially, the idea at United is to sell the front of the plane at full fare and fill in the back with yield-managed fares that are still higher than the going rate on discount airlines. And the only way to do that, United believes, is to fly airplanes that offer that kind of premium service business travelers have become accustomed to on international flights, including flat-bed seats in first class and meal service that he says will be up to international airlines' standards.
 This idea, coming from an airline that has been in bankruptcy since December 2002 and that is reportedly considering a further work force reduction of 6,000 employees, has generated some derision, especially from analysts who insist that domestic air travel has become little more than a commodity. But Joe Brancatelli, who is not shy about ridiculing the business tactics of the major carriers on his popular business-travel Web site, Joesentme.com, was willing to concede that United's argument about the transcontinental premium niche made some sense. On paper.
 ''In transcon, this is basically a good idea,'' he said. ''Who can argue with lie-flat beds in first class, a much upgraded business class, and 34 inches of seat pitch in every coach chair? 
 ''But for United business travelers, this also introduces problems. One, it's another bizarre configuration in an airline that's all over the map. When you book United now, what in the world are you booking? Ted? Old-line United? United Premium Service? Regional jets flying 1,500-mile trips? And it adds even more confusion and complexity to the fare structure.'' 
 And so far, the marketing of p.s. to United's frequent fliers has been muddled, leaving potential passengers confused about when the new service will actually be available. ''United is already behind the eight ball on this,'' he said. ''It's really going to be the end of February before they get this all lined up, and in the meantime the logistics can eat them alive.''
 Not so, Mr. White says. United is reconfiguring 13 of its 757's for the routes. The first flight is scheduled for Oct. 17 from Kennedy to Los Angeles, and all six aircraft designated for those daily routes should be converted by mid-December, Mr. White said. The six planes for the San Francisco routes will start flying in January, with the entire fleet converted by late February, he said. (One 757 will be held in reserve.)
 The 757's flying p.s. service will offer 12 flat-bed seats in first class, 26 seats with 54 inches of pitch in business class, and 72 seats in economy class. That's 110 seats. The 767's currently flying those routes have 182 seats, he said.
 ''The fares stay the same'' as they are now, he said. Those are published fares, roughly the same as American's. But right now, in the first and business cabins on those routes, both airlines have a lot of frequent-flier passengers who have been upgraded -- that is, flying in the expensive seats on a cheap ticket. United's new p.s. service, Mr. White said, is intended to entice more travelers, including those from American Airlines, a unit of AMR, to pay full fare. ''With a better product we feel we can sell more of those seats, which means we'd need to upgrade fewer.''
 Upgrade fewer? I'll bet that just got the rapt attention of a lot of United frequent fliers on the transcontinental trail.

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Small Business; AGRICULTURE; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1222 words

HEADLINE: Sell in Bulk, Lose Farm. Sell Locally, and Watch Revenues Grow.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER. 
Keith Schneider, a former New York Times reporter, is deputy director of the Michigan Land Use Institute.

DATELINE: KALKASKA, Mich. 

 BODY:
ONE of the truly good-news stories in American agriculture, and one with meaning for small businesses of all kinds, is what's happening on Tyler Road here at the Shetler Family Dairy.
 Not that long ago, George and Sally Shetler were small fry in an industry dominated by big players, producers of a bulk commodity in which prices essentially had not budged for 20 years. Continuing to supply the conventional fluid milk market, the Shetlers concluded, would take them down the same bankruptcy path that the Department of Agriculture says claimed almost 400 farms a week from 1974 to the mid-1990's, most of them small. 
 So in 1995, the Shetlers decided to try a more entrepreneurial approach. If the markets they could reach through conventional channels were unsatisfactory, what new market could they tap? 
 The one right around them, as it turned out -- bottling and delivering their milk directly to stores in Traverse City, 25 miles away, the center of a five-county region with 165,000 residents and growing faster than almost any place in the Midwest.
 The couple, who raised five children in a 90-year-old farmhouse with one bathroom and a lot of wallpaper with cows, sent a survey to local markets and learned that proprietors were eager to sell fresh food produced by local growers. They then sat at their dining table and wrote a straightforward business plan on one page of unlined white paper -- ''Start small within 1995. Action to be taken: Pray!!'' -- that accurately described the fast-growing business they and several of their children operate.
 Today, the milk from its 38 cows is bottled in a $140,000 microcreamery the family built and stocked with used equipment. The dairy ships 1,300 gallons of milk and dairy products twice a week to 50 stores in the Grand Traverse region. Their truck has a set of Texas longhorns bolted to the roof of the cab, a black-and-white Holstein pattern and a slogan: ''From Moo to You.'' 
 The result? Revenues have grown fourfold, and the farm now has seven employees.
 ''You know what this has done for us? Every other weekend now I get off and don't have to milk,'' said Mr. Shetler, 53, who bought his 180-acre farm 25 years ago.
 There are other examples of how the adage in agriculture to ''get big or get out'' is being turned on its head by growers who are staying small, and getting much more profitable. Mike and Tina Werp, for instance, produce specialty baby vegetables for 15 restaurants in Traverse City, Detroit and Mackinac Island, one of the state's top tourist destinations. They have an 80-acre farm in Grant Township, which is south of Traverse City, but do most of the cultivating in greenhouses and fields on just 10 acres. Their total annual revenue is $150,000, or $15,000 an acre. 
 Revenue, moreover, is growing steadily and is enough to employ three full-time and three part-time workers. By contrast, conventional corn growers in the region are fortunate if they earn $300 an acre. ''The idea is to do things intelligently,'' said Mr. Werp, an engineer who was raised in Detroit but migrated to the region in the mid-1970's to manage the farm, which was owned by his grandparents. ''I'm not trying to do what Ford, G.M. and Chrysler try to do. I don't need my vegetables to be in every community.''
 Entrepreneurial farms are largely invisible to government and economic development agencies, said Bill Palladino, a small-business development specialist in the Traverse City region. ''We know it is a core economy for our region,'' Mr. Palladino said, ''but we don't know how big it is yet. We want to know. The value-added ag economy is based locally, uses local resources, and takes those resources and extends them to the marketplace here.''
 The success of Shetler Family Dairy, Werp Farms and dozens of other small growers in northern Michigan has attracted the attention of the Traverse City Area Chamber of Commerce. The chamber's foundation joined the W. K. Kellogg Foundation in Battle Creek, Mich., which co-sponsored the publication of a regional food guide, prepared by the Michigan Land Use Institute, to link small farmers with local customers.
 The basic idea of putting buyers and sellers of homegrown food together, of course, is not new. Farmers' markets have existed as long as the republic. But farmers' ingenuity in tapping new markets, and consumers' eagerness for farm-fresh foods, are both on the rise, according to the Department of Agriculture. And local and state governments and the business community are doing more to support the trend, recognizing that small farms are linked to other useful economic, environmental and cultural outcomes.
 For instance, Douglas Luciani, the president of the Traverse City Area Chamber of Commerce, , said that farms provide scenic open space that helps attract tourists and puts a brake on some of the unmanaged development and sprawl.
 Similar views are expressed in dozens of fast-growing urban and suburban communities nationwide. The number of farms that are 10 to 49 acres actually increased to 563,772 in 2002 from 530,902 in 1997, according to the latest farm census by the Department of Agriculture. Some of those farms are in Community Supported Agriculture programs, known as C.S.A.'s, which sell shares to customers during the winter for a portion of their summer production. There are now more than 1,700 C.S.A.'s, according to an article on NewFarm.org, a Web site of the nonprofit group Rodale Institute. 
 Farmers are driving the innovation in new markets. In Lincoln, Neb., earlier this year, a group of 10 farmers opened what most authorities think is the only grocery store in the nation owned and managed by growers. The 5,000-square-foot Centerville Farmers' Market in the historic Haymarket district occupies the first floor of a renovated steam-tractor factory. John Ellis, a farmer and the store manager, said the store was intended to operate year-round featuring homegrown, mostly chemical-free fruits, vegetables, meats (including buffalo, ostrich and emu), dairy products and other foods produced by 31 growers. It cost $75,000 to prepare the space, and business has been brisk. ''We're attracting some attention and we're developing our market,'' Mr. Ellis said.
 Consumers are not the only people taking an interest in locally grown food. State governments are beginning to see small family farms as an asset capable of generating jobs and slowing suburban sprawl. In Massachusetts, for instance, the Farm Viability Enhancement Program has helped 139 family farms, or 2 percent of the state's total, stay in business by making grants to farms for new marketing projects.
 Last year, Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm introduced Select a Taste of Michigan, a program to promote asparagus and nine other fresh market crops. Rick Oomen, 49, a vegetable farmer in Hart, credited the program with raising prices. ''The last two years, we've enjoyed the best fresh market prices I can remember,'' he said.
 Such optimism is striking in an industry where bad news is generally the norm. Not so for many of the state's 52,000 farms, including the Shetlers'. Though there were days when the Shetlers thought they might lose the farm, those have passed. ''Before we started bottling milk it was always at the back of my mind -- do something,'' Mrs. Shetler said. ''We did and it's working out.''

 EARLY RISER -- George Shetler is up at 4 a.m. on his dairy farm, which sells directly to local stores. That strategy has led to a fourfold growth in revenues. (Photographs by Gary Howe for The New York Times)
