HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

Now Playing

''THE BROWN BUNNY,'' starring Vincent Gallo and Chloe Sevigny. Written and directed by Mr. Gallo (not rated, 92 minutes). Neither an atrocity nor a revelation, ''The Brown Bunny'' is a very watchable, often beautiful-looking attempt by Mr. Gallo to reproduce the kind of loosely structured mood pieces that found American and select foreign-language cinema of the 1960's and 70's often at its most adventurous, with Monte Hellman's 1971 ''Two-Lane Blacktop'' the most obvious touchstone. Mr. Gallo plays Bud Clay, a motorcycle racer (and the title's symbolic bunny) on his way back home to Los Angeles from a New Hampshire meet. As Bud racks up miles, he stares moodily at the road, visits a childhood haunt, eats a lonely meal, sleeps a lonely motel sleep, takes his motorcycle for a spin and exchanges small talk with a few women, all of whom have the soft, bruised look of chronic disappointment. Eventually Bud hits Los Angeles, where he checks into a hotel, and where yet another flower of femininity, Ms. Sevigny's Daisy, gives the film its back story and furnishes what the porn industry calls, in rather more direct language, its economic raison d'etre (Manohla Dargis).

* ''CELLULAR,'' starring Kim Basinger, Chris Evans and William H. Macy (PG-13, 89 minutes). In this improbable, improbably entertaining action thriller, a Los Angeles science teacher (Ms. Basinger) is kidnapped by a squad of baddies who lock her in an attic with a telephone that works just well enough for her to connect, at random, with the cell phone of a surfer (Mr. Evans), who spends the rest of the movie trying to rescue her. In an age of self-important, bloated blockbusters, this movie, directed with breeziness and rigor by Mr. Ellis, is a refreshing rarity: an honest, unpretentious B picture, with enough decent jokes, crackerjack car chases and plot convolutions to make the price of the ticket seem like a reasonable bargain. Mr. Macy adds a wry, touching note as the weary L.A.P.D. veteran who helps the surfer in his effort to save the science teacher (A. O. Scott).

* ''COLLATERAL,'' starring Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 115 minutes). In ''Collateral,'' the edgy new thriller from Mr. Mann, the city never sleeps; it doesn't even relax. Set in Los Angeles mostly after dark, after the sunshine has given way to cool noir, the story centers on a taxi driver, Max (Mr. Foxx), and the assassin Vincent (Mr. Cruise), who hops a ride with him deep into the night. Pitched between interludes of anxious intimacy and equally nerve-shredding set pieces, ''Collateral'' scores its points with underhand precision. The film is about a lot of different things, about how Los Angeles lights up even at night, how cars become prostheses of ourselves and how driving with the radio on can be bliss. But as with all of Mr. Mann's movies, ''Collateral'' is finally about men and work, and about how being a man is itself a kind of job, which explains why this fastidiously made commercial film isn't just an entertainment, but a statement of personal faith (Dargis).

''CRIMINAL,'' starring John C. Reilly, Diego Luna and Maggie Gyllenhaal. Directed by Gregory Jacobs (R, 87 minutes). Mr. Reilly may be one of our finer character actors, but his portrayal in ''Criminal'' of a gimlet-eyed con man allows too many vestiges of the duped schlub of a husband he played in ''Chicago'' to leak into his performance. But the Mametesque film has strong supporting performances by Mr. Luna, as Mr. Reilly's not-so-naive protege in swindling, and Ms. Gyllenhaal, as Mr. Reilly's angry sister. The film, a fairly faithful adaptation of the Argentine director Fabian Bielinski's ''Nine Queens,'' is a clever and diverting caper, relocated from South America to Los Angeles. Instead of rare stamps being pursued by assorted grifters and counterfeiters, the priceless fetish being sought is the counterfeit of an 1878 Monroe silver certificate. Mr. Mamet covered roughly the same territory with far more zest and cunning in ''House of Games,'' a movie that unlike ''Criminal'' leaves you with the uneasy sense of living in a world run by diabolically clever thieves gloating over the naivete of suckers like you and me (Stephen Holden).

* ''GHOST IN THE SHELL 2: INNOCENCE,'' with the voices of Akio Otsuka and Atsukko Tanaka. Directed by Mamoru Oshii (PG-13, 99 minutes; in Japanese, with subtitles). Androids don't dream of electric sheep in Mr. Oshii's hallucinatory meditation on life in the shadow of the machine world. They dream of suicide, an unlikely act of violence that one android or ''gynoid,'' a sexual pet with a tragic face and luridly flexible limbs, commits by clawing at its synthetic skin like a grieving widow. This movie is a sequel to the Japanese filmmaker's 1995 anime, ''Ghost in the Shell,'' about a female detective who inhabits and then loses her artificial body. Set in 2032, the new anime centers on her former colleague, the stone-faced cyborg Batou, a male cop who trowels a future-shock world in which sex dolls commit virtual seppuku against a swirl of film-noir intrigue, philosophical speculation, eye-popping images and serious science-fiction cool, and where machines often seem more human their human masters (Dargis).

''HERO,'' starring Jet Li. Directed by Zhang Yimou (PG-13, 99 minutes; in Mandarin, with English subtitles). In Mr. Zhang's ''Hero,'' an ambitious period epic about the birth of the first Chinese empire, warriors fly through the air like birds of prey, their swords cutting through enemies and lovers alike. Set during the third century B.C., the story of an assassination plot unfolds with such dazzling bursts of color and blurs of furious action that it might be easy to miss the nationalistic message tucked amid the visual enchantments. The martial-arts film star Jet Li is the title's nameless warrior, who claims to have vanquished the king's most feared enemies, Sky (Donnie Yen), Snow (Maggie Cheung Man-yuk) and the powerful Broken Sword (Tony Leung Chiu-wai). In time, Nameless spins a second, a third and finally a fourth version, changes in perspective that Mr. Zhang signals with shifts of color that flood the screen with a red as vivid as that of a Little Red Book, a spotless white, a delicate blue and a pale pistachio so mouthwatering you may want to lick the screen. Roll over, Chairman Mao, and tell the comrades the news: the history of the empire now comes wrapped in kaleidoscopic kung fu cool (Dargis).

* ''MARIA FULL OF GRACE,'' starring Catalina Sandino Moreno and Yenny Paola Vega. Written and directed by Joshua Marston (R, 101 minutes; in Spanish, with English subtitles). It's painfully understandable why the 17-year-old title character of this gripping Colombian film would risk her freedom and even her life to be a drug mule. The movie follows the desperate plunge of Maria (Ms. Sandino) from a dead-end job as an assembly-line worker in a Colombian flower factory into the drug-smuggling underworld. Her dangerous undertaking is her last resort when she finds herself unemployed and pregnant. Before the story zeroes in on the harrowing details of drug running and its dangers, it details Maria's hopelessly circumscribed life in a rural village. If her story is a template for countless others like it, what keeps your heart in your throat is Maria herself. In a performance that feels more lived in than acted, Ms. Sandino's Maria is an attractive, smart, spirited young woman who faces the challenge of fending for herself with a fierce determination and ingenuity that compromise but never undermine her essential decency and morality. The movie sustains a documentary authenticity that is as astonishing as it is off-handed. Even while keeping you on the edge of your seat, it never sacrifices a calm, clear-sighted humanity for the sake of melodrama or cheap moralizing (Holden).

* ''RED LIGHTS,'' starring Jean-Pierre Darroussin and Carole Bouquet. Directed by Cedric Kahn (not rated, 106 minutes; in French with English subtitles). This brilliant, sinister French thriller is a twisty road movie in which every sign points toward catastrophe. As night falls during the journey of an unhappily married couple from Paris to Bordeaux, the clogged highway takes them into descending levels of psychosexual hell. Mr. Darroussin's Antoine is a mousy, balding insurance salesman who hates his job and resents his more successful wife, a sleek corporate lawyer. The movie is a study of male passive aggression that comes up with a malicious Hemingwayesque solution to Antoine's masculinity crisis. When his wife, fed up with his drinking on the road, deserts him to take the train, he picks up a hitchhiker he knows may be a dangerous escaped convict and courts the redemptive (and grisly) male rite of passage he's been seeking. Following Jean-Luc Godard's ''Weekend'' and Claire Denis's ''Friday Night,'' ''Red Lights'' uses the traffic jam as a potent screen metaphor for something bigger (Holden).

''SILVER CITY,'' starring Chris Cooper, Danny Huston and Richard Dreyfuss. Written and directed by John Sayles (R, 124 minutes). In his latest lesson in How the World Really Works, Mr. Sayles cooks up a conspiracy of politicians, land developers and big corporations in Colorado colluding to despoil the envirnonment and oppress the workers. It falls to a disgraced journalist-turned-private-eye named Danny O'Brien (Mr. Huston) to unravel the skeins of greed and corruption that threaten the state of Colorado. His investigation consists mainly of long, expository conversations with victims and accomplices, and after a while the movie begins to feel like a long episode of ''The Rockford Files'' written by the staff of The Nation. The issue is not whether Mr. Sayles is right about the nature of political power and economic influence, but whether he can be bothered to embed his ethical and political concerns in a persuasive human reality. He can't, in spite of the good work of a talented cast, including Mr. Cooper as a gubernatorial candidate named Dickie Pilager, a mean (and dated) caricature of George W. Bush that Mr. Cooper cannot help but endow with the hint of a soul (Scott).

''SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW,'' starring Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Angelina Jolie and Giovanni Ribisi. Written and directed by Kerry Conran (PG, 107 minutes). In this movie's elegant murk, Mr. Law and Ms. Paltrow slip into comic-book archetypes of the dashing aviator and the intrepid girl reporter with supreme confidence. But can the movie establish a swashbuckling franchise as commercially potent as the Indiana Jones movies? When Mr. Conran's remarkable filmmaking debut remembers that storytelling and characters matter more than design and special effects, the movie charms as well as impresses. If nothing else, it is a landmark of computer-generated images whose actors cavort through an entirely synthetic, retro-styled future world that fuses Art Deco, Futurism, Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis'' and the spirit of the 1939 World's Fair into an all-purpose eve-of-World War II environment extrapolated into a science-fiction limbo. But its visual elegance comes at a price. Its ethereal evocation of a pulp-fiction future-past eclipses almost any other sci-fi franchise in subtlety and imagination, but shadowy washed-out color is a far cry from the robust hues of a movie like ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.'' At times, it's hard to see what's on the screen (Holden).

''VANITY FAIR,'' starring Reese Witherspoon and James Purefoy. Directed by Mira Nair (PG-13, 141 minutes). Her eyes snapping like tiny firecrackers, Ms. Witherspoon makes an appealingly crafty Becky Sharp in Ms. Nair's bland but color-drenched screen adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray's 1848 novel. The star, as usual, conveys a bristly, determined spunk. But if her performance emits enough sparks to hold the screen, it never ignites a dramatic brush fire. You long for more Scarlett O'Hara and less Elle Woods. Her Becky comes across as a lightweight schemer about as formidable as an aspiring trophy wife on a daytime soap. In compressing a novel that spans three decades of the early 19th century, the movie becomes increasingly hurried and eventually loses track of time, and in trying to mix satire and romance it proves once again that the two are about as compatible as lemon juice and heavy cream. It flashes to comic life in those scenes that convey Thackeray's disdain for the preening foolishness and snobbery of early 19th-century English society and the crass symbiotic relationship between money and aristocracy (Holden).

''WIMBLEDON,'' starring Kirsten Dunst and Paul Bettany. Directed by Richard Loncraine (PG-13, 100 minutes). Will pre-game sexual high jinks give you the edge you need to win at tennis? Or will they distract you from mobilizing the killer instinct necessary to blast through to victory? That's the earth-shattering question at the heart of ''Wimbledon,'' a likable, formulaic sports movie that follows the miraculous comeback of an insecure 31-year-old British tennis pro named Peter (Mr. Bettany) whose career resurrects on the wings of love. At Wimbledon, where he's playing his final professional matches, he meets and falls in love with Lizzie, a super-competitive American pro (Ms. Dunst) on the fast track to the women's championship. She appears unstoppable until Peter enters her life. The moment her defenses start to crumble, her concentration falters. As the trajectories of their careers reverse, Peter credits Lizzie with spurring his triumphs, while she bitterly blames him for her fall from grace. The film's most refreshing idea is to present a male sports hero who doesn't see himself primarily as an invincible fighting machine. He is courtly, witty, sensitive and apologetic to a fault (Holden).

HEADLINE: With Yankees Coming, Red Sox Hope To Keep the Party From Turning Ugly

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
On the pavement of Yawkey Way outside Fenway Park on Thursday night, amid the smells of grilled sausages and many other foods, a young man on stilts wore a Red Sox uniform that said ''Big League Brian'' on the back.
 He walked steadily, in a practiced way, next to the Hot Tamale Brass Band, which was serenading fans with ''Besame Mucho'' as they filed into the game between the Red Sox and the Baltimore Orioles.
 The temperature was 66 degrees, the clear sky was streaked with the reds of autumn's setting sun, the wind and humidity were low and a bright half-moon rose in the backdrop between buildings. The working conditions were not too shabby. ''I love my job,'' Big League Brian said. ''Nothing like walking around a bunch of drunk people on stilts.'' 
 He spoke in jest before a 9-7 defeat that left the Red Sox four and a half games behind the Yankees in the race for first place in the American League East. Although some of the fans were drinking, the crowd was mellow and smiling.
 They did not leave as happy, however. The Red Sox were on the verge of a third consecutive victory in their last at-bat after Manny Ramirez's two-run single with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth. That brought up David Ortiz, but his fly ball to right field was caught on the warning track.
 Now the Red Sox' archrivals from the Bronx arrive for three games this weekend to finish Boston's home schedule before the playoffs. The Red Sox probably will qualify as the A.L. wild card; the Yankees clinched a playoff spot on Thursday.
 Of course, all the tickets are sold for the weekend. In the smallest and oldest major league ballpark, with a capacity of 36,298, every ticket has been sold for every game this year, the first time in Red Sox history. Business has never been better in America's quaintest, quirkiest sports theater.
 For the past two years, Yawkey Way has become an extension of the park on game days, with turnstiles set up on the corners and the street used as an extended concourse. Later Thursday night, many fans with tickets stayed out on the street, watching the game on a big television picture projected from the ballpark onto the wide, white wall of a building across the street. That started just this week.
 Nearby, Mickey Bones, the drummer and leader of the Hot Tamale Brass Band, was counting the dollar-bill tips in his instrument case as he said: ''This is our regular gig. We've been doing it for six or seven years.''
 Bones said the Fenway crowds seem bigger and a little more raucous when the Yankees are in town, perhaps because everyone who buys a ticket uses it. He said one of the perks of his job is that he and his musical mates get to see every game free. ''Standing room only,'' said Bones, of Salem, Mass.
 When tickets are in such demand, they create their own economic forces, and the Red Sox hope to crack down on scalping. They said this week that employees of the team, under cover, have begun to buy seats on the streets and over the Internet. If they can trace the tickets back to season-ticket holders, they may cancel the subscriptions. 
 If people wish to sell extra tickets at face value, the team will soon establish a ''scalp-free zone'' near the gates so that fans can avoid legal problems. The Orioles have a similar setup at Camden Yards.
 Charles J. Cellucci, the Red Sox' director of security, said he could not predict how well the plan would work. Cellucci, a former deputy superintendent of the Boston police, said the stadium was so small that few people would have extra tickets.
 ''We'll give it a shot and see if we get any participation,'' Cellucci said.
 The average ticket price is $43, but seats are offered for this weekend by some ticket brokers for several hundred dollars each. 
 Cellucci said that when the Yankees are in town, he uses the maximum staff for ballpark security and a police detail that is double the size of a normal game. There have been past incidents between fans and Yankees players, and a bullpen brawl last year involved a groundskeeper.
 Cellucci said he was trying to cut down on confrontations and other unpleasantness by training staff members to be proactive and conversational with customers and to project ''a positive attitude instead of a negative attitude'' when addressing rowdy behavior in its early stages. 
 If it does not work, he said, ''we take a strong stand and eject them.'' 
 And what did Cellucci predict for this Yankees weekend?
 ''A busy one, but I think it will be a safe one,'' he said. ''We've got maximum deployment, maximum coverage. Our supervisors will be right on top of this.''

HEADLINE: Retired? Yes. Retiring? No.

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE

DATELINE: ST. GEORGE, Utah 

 BODY:
AT daybreak on a recent morning, the average age on the Virgin River Trail hovered between AARP eligibility and Medicare beneficiary, settling in somewhere north of 60. As Bill Boulter biked up the mesquite-lined path in a 20-mile loop, he passed a parade of gray-bearded grandfathers on recumbent bicycles, silver-haired joggers covered in Lycra and liver spots, and power walkers with walking sticks. 
 ''I call them raisins because they're all wrinkly and slow,'' said Mr. Boulter, 60 and a grandfather. ''But I should talk. I'm rapidly becoming a raisin myself.''
 In the latest twist on retirement living, aging baby boomers are abandoning the surf-and-turf enclaves of Florida or Arizona, in favor of fitness-minded enclaves where they can raft, rock climb and hike well into old age. The new retirees are sort of a senior version of college-age ski bums, migrating to resort towns not to work but to play all day. ''They aren't getting their gold watch and sitting on a rocking chair,'' said Amber McCracken, a spokeswoman for the Alliance for Aging Research based in Washington. 
 And with 38 million older baby boomers nearing retirement age, communities catering to grizzled jocks are starting to emerge wherever the winters are mild, the land is relatively affordable and the great outdoors is a short hop away. Many have cropped up in the Pacific Northwest and the Rockies, places like Hood River, Ore.; Durango, Colo.; and other small resort towns that offer a dizzying array of outdoor activities.
 ''We see retirees as tourists who stay longer,'' said James Westkott, a state demographer for Colorado, which has had a surge of ''interim retirees,'' affluent boomers who are enjoying active retirement in their 50's. ''These places were developed as second-home communities, but are now being turned into retirement communities.'' 
 The trendsetter, however, may be Washington County and its hub city, St. George, in the southwest corner of Utah, near the Arizona and Nevada borders and two hours northeast of Las Vegas. ''It's the fastest-growing retirement community in the country,'' said John Burns, a real estate consultant from Irvine, Calif., who has written extensively about retirement migration. 
 The allure is not hard to see. Etched into the red-rock cliffs, St. George offers a seemingly endless array of hiking and biking trails. Eight national and state parks are within close driving distance, including the North Rim of the Grand Canyon and Zion National Park. The city itself has a 30-mile network of trails along the Virgin and Santa Clara Rivers that connect with longer paths. Two teal-blue reservoirs double as parks and marinas. A third lake will be at Sand Hollow Reservoir State Park, which is nearing completion and will offer boating, fishing, water-skiing, off-road driving and even more hiking.
 Then there are the city's 10 golf courses, but they are less popular than many had anticipated. ''My dad played golf,'' smirked Art Miller, 64, a retired civil engineer who moved to St. George from the Denver area.
 For many retirees, the area looks like one giant playground. ''I don't think of it as retiring,'' said Paul Alcantra, 68, a former president of Eastern Sierra College Center in Bishop, Calif., who moved to St. George two years ago, with his wife, Edna. ''I think of it as refocusing.'' These days, his focus is on exploring new hikes, working on his pickle ball (a variant of tennis) and installing a weight room in his new 2,300-square-foot house. ''I can bench press 250 pounds,'' he said. 
 RETIREES began moving to St. George in large numbers in the early 1990's, having learned about it through word of mouth or having discovered the town en route to Zion. Still others came because St. George, to them, is where old people go to become jocks. Every October, thousands of athletes ages 50 and up converge at St. George for the Huntsman World Senior Games, an Olympics-style competition that adds a new twist to the term ''senior varsity.'' Now in its 18th year, the tournament pits elders against elders in 22 sports, from downhill mountain biking to the Senior Games' answer to synchronized swimming: square dancing.
 By 2000, adults ages 60 and older made up nearly a quarter of the city's 50,000 residents, compared with the national average of 16 percent. Developers spotted a real estate gold mine and began building communities to attract more retirees to the area.
 ''St. George was a perfect mix,'' said Darcy Stewart, the developer of SunRiver, the largest adult community in the area. ''It offers a warm climate, proximity to Las Vegas and all the outdoor things that retired people are looking for.''
 Built in 1998 on the outskirts of St. George, SunRiver has 600 homes that vaguely resemble Spanish Colonial villas. But unlike traditional housing restricted to ages 55 and higher, SunRiver makes no mention of the word ''retirement,'' and feels more like a college campus for graying students than a nursing home disguised as a country club. At the heart of SunRiver is a recreation center with a circuit-training gym, swimming pool, dance studio, locker rooms and a ballroom. The front desk distributes a monthly calendar that lists as many as a half-dozen activities a day, from long hikes to tai chi. Adjacent to the center are seven tennis and pickle ball courts, a patch of green for lawn bowling and a clubhouse for the 18-hole golf course that rings the entire property.
 In a sense, SunRiver is not so different from Sun City in Phoenix, the retirement development built four decades ago by the Del Webb Corporation that spawned a new genre of ''active adult'' communities. But SunRiver is much smaller, only 1,200 residents, compared with the more than 45,000 who live in Sun City. Moreover, SunRiver was designed to be a neighborhood of St. George, not a resort city onto itself. ''We looked at Sun City, but the population was too old,'' said Janet Odle, 62, who moved here two years ago from California. ''We like the fact that there's younger people around.''
 Indeed, only a small fraction of the retirees in St. George live in adult communities. The vast majority are scattered throughout the city, in dozens of other planned developments with names like Coral Canyon and Garden Park that are not restricted to those 55 and older.
 Signs of retirees in training are everywhere. Twice a week, Gary Thayne, 58, takes a break from his triathlon training and launches a small speedboat into the Quail Creek State Park and Reservoir, about 13 miles northeast of St. George. Once afloat, Mr. Thayne puts on a life jacket and jumps into the water with his Sky Ski -- a tethered apparatus that resembles a snowboard with a hydrofoil fin. With his son-in-law at the wheel, he holds onto a rope as he flies over the water, mimicking a human jet ski. 
 ''We're just amateurs,'' Mr. Thayne said after his run, wiping himself dry. ''Come back in two years, and we'll be doing 360-degree stunts in the air.''
 ''I need to stay fit to keep up with all the other geezers,'' said Biff Lowry, 77, who could be described as the Mark Spitz of his generation (he took home seven gold medals in swimming at the Huntsman Games two years ago). Every morning, Mr. Lowry reports to the Sand Hollow Aquatic Center in St. George, where he strips down to his bathing suit, dons a white rubber cap and does more than a mile by lunchtime. ''There's a guy who just turned 75 who is remarkable,'' he said of another swimmer.
 But the fiercest competition may be among the older baby boomers, who are hitting 58 this year. Instead of treating retirement as a time to withdraw from the world, as their parents' generation did, many boomers seem to see retirement as just another challenge. For them, retirement is a continuing adventure, not a permanent vacation.
 ''It is no longer God's waiting room,'' said Daniel Perry, executive director at the Alliance for Aging Research. ''Baby boomers are much healthier. Not only do they enjoy a longer life expectancy, but they are less disabled. And they are determined not to age the way that past generations have.''
THAT would rule out playing bingo in Boca Raton, Fla. ''Boomers aren't going to sit back and just collect from the government,'' said Edward L. Schneider, dean emeritus at the University of Southern California's Leonard Davis School of Gerontology. ''They are looking forward to doing things they hadn't done before.''
 They are also moving to places that their parents only visited. ''You'll see seniors next to national parks, near the seashore, or wherever they can stay active and stay vital,'' Dr. Schneider said. ''They are looking for a one-story house, located in a community where they can have lots of recreation and lots of exercise.''
 Home builders, in response, are starting to go outside the traditional Sun Belt and into places as varied as the lush forests of Redmond, Wash., and the foothills of the Colorado Rockies. ''It's a very significant shift,'' said Gopal Ahluwalia, an economist and vice president of research at the National Association of Home Builders. ''Before, the proximity to the doctor's office and hospital were the main concerns. Now, the most important things are walking and jogging trails.''
 That was certainly the clincher for Mr. Boulter and his wife, Terri, who moved to St. George this summer, even though Mr. Boulter does not plan to retire from the pacemaker business for several years. But why stay in Dallas, Mr. Boulter figured, when he could ''bike here all year long'' and ease into retirement gracefully. ''If I can still beat my son at racquetball and ride my bike for 50 miles,'' he asked, ''how old can I be?''

HOT SPOTS
Getting Older and Getting Better, at Rock Climbing or Soccer

Rio Vista, Calif.

WHERE -- On the banks of the Sacramento River Delta, about 50 miles southwest of Sacramento.

WHY -- Fishing is king here, but the area also offers boating, sailing and yachting. The Black Diamond Mines Regional Preserve and Mount Diablo State Park are within easy driving distance.

HOUSING -- Trilogy at Rio Vista, a subsidiary of the Shea Homes, is an 800-acre planned community that currently has 1,200 homes, a health club, an 18-hole golf course and extensive walking trails. Prices range from $303,999 for a 1,153-square-foot two-bedroom house to $488,999 for a two-bedroom 2,541-square-foot unit. At Homecoming, another new development, a two-bedroom house with two bathrooms is offered at $330,000.

ACTIVITIES -- An hour away, the California Senior Games Sacramento Sports Classic is an annual spring event involving sports as diverse as archery, soccer and track. Salsa and tango are included in a ballroom dancing competition along with waltzes and fox trots.

Durango, Colo.

WHERE -- Near the San Juan National Forest, in the Four Corners area where Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Arizona meet.

WHY -- This artsy resort town with a population of 15,000 is near skiing (Durango Mountain Resort, formerly Purgatory, is about 25 miles north of town). The jagged and lush terrain also caters to hikers, cyclists and rock climbers. Nearby rivers and lakes offer fishing and rafting.

HOUSING -- Brookstone, just northeast of town, has 1,680- to 1,880-square-foot condominiums, for ages 55 and over, ranging from $359,000 to $439,000. Most retirees, however, live in houses originally purchased as second homes. Currently on the market is a three-bedroom log house on four acres with a two-car garage at $305,000.

ACTIVITIES -- Seniors Outdoors!, a volunteer-run group, organizes hikes, rock-climbing trips and other excursions.

Hood River, Ore.

WHERE -- The scenic crossroads of the Columbia River Gorge and the Cascade Mountain Range, 60 miles east of Portland.

WHY -- The diverse geography lends itself to a wide range of outdoor activities, from kayaking and sailing on the Columbia River to hiking and climbing in the mountains.

HOUSING -- Hood River, population 5,800, has few planned adult communities. Construction of Highlands at Indian Creek, a 55-and-older community, began in 2000, and the last two units were sold last summer. The community consists of six buildings with three units each, ranging from 1,900 to 3,000 square feet and starting at $275,000. On the market now is a three-bedroom, 1,500 square-foot ranch-style house with views of Mount Adams for $225,000. A three-bedroom house under construction on .14 acres in a new subdivision on the west side of the Hood River is offered at $218,000.

ACTIVITIES -- The old Columbia River Highway is popular with hikers, bicyclists and bird watchers. The waterfront also attracts many older windsurfers.

SECTION: Section E; PT1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; FILM REVIEW; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 618 words

HEADLINE: Lights! Camera! Sting! Popcorn and Pirandello Are Taking On the Mob

BYLINE: By A. O. SCOTT

 BODY:
Movies are sometimes made for strange reasons, and sometimes for no good reason at all. ''The Last Shot,'' an R-rated comedy from Disney which opens today nationwide, is about the first kind of movie, but unfortunately it belongs to the second type. Adapted from a nonfiction magazine article, it tells the improbable ''making of'' story of a film that was never actually made, but that was part of an F.B.I. sting operation aimed at the mob in Providence, R.I. 
 To ensnare a mid-level boss who controls a corrupt union local, an enterprising undercover agent (Alec Baldwin) poses as a Hollywood producer, setting up an elaborate and phony project, complete with lights, cameras, stars and an unsuspecting director (Matthew Broderick).
 From time to time, as ''The Last Shot'' rambles and stumbles through a hectic, slipshod plot, a spark of clever movie-industry satire pops into view. Joan Cusack, uncredited in the opening titles, rants and trills through two uproarious scenes as a fast-talking agent. Toni Collette, as the platinum-blond star of the movie-within-the-movie, is a vision of fluttery narcissism. Mr. Baldwin, beefy and stoical, manages a few deadpan jokes, and his bureau supervisors give notes as if they were real-life studio executives.
 But despite these moments and a promising conceit, the movie, written and directed by Jeff Nathanson (whose screenwriting credits include ''The Terminal''), is laborious and logy when it should be madcap and effervescent.
 Mr. Broderick's character, Steven Schats, is a failed screenwriter who pays the rent taking tickets at Grauman's Chinese Theater and lives above a kennel with his high-strung girlfriend (Calista Flockhart), an aspiring actress. Agent Devine (Mr. Baldwin), whom the plot contrives to make a dog-lover in mourning, arrives out of nowhere to greenlight Steven's project, a New Age romantic melodrama called ''Arizona,'' which for reasons of law-enforcement must be shot in the gray, snowy streets of Rhode Island. It is gratifying to note that Providence, rather than being impersonated by some Canadian city, is mostly allowed to play itself -- its younger self, at any rate. The movie, set in 1985, features period-appropriate boxy sedans and giant cellphones, but also many anachronistic views of that city's radically rebuilt downtown.
 A lot of time is spent gazing at scenery, waiting for something interesting to happen. There is no shortage of incident, but the story trips in a half-dozen directions. Steven and Agent Devine are given parallel sibling-rivalry subplots, which serve mainly as excuses to bring Tim Blake Nelson and Ray Liotta a few moments of irrelevant screen time.
 The mood is no more consistent than the narrative, veering from puppy-dog sweetness to hard-edged vulgarity to antic spoofiness. In the case of ''Arizona,'' the feds ultimately pull the plug. Disney might have learned something from them.
 ''The Last Shot'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has vulgarity, sexual situations and brief nudity.

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Portrait Vanishes From Historical Society
 A portrait of Dr. David Hosack, a prominent surgeon who attended Alexander Hamilton on his deathbed after that legendary duel, has vanished from the New-York Historical Society's $5 million-plus exhibition ''Alexander Hamilton, the Man Who Made Modern America.''
 No, it wasn't stolen. 
 Apparently the designer of the exhibition, Ralph Appelbaum, installed a low railing to keep viewers in the portrait gallery from getting too close to the paintings. During the installation Rob del Bagno, the museum's head of exhibition and design services, tripped over the railing and recommended that it be removed. It wasn't.
 So on Sept. 10, the first day of the show, a visitor tripped over the railing while leaning forward to get a look at the portrait and poked his hand through the canvas. The visitor actually had to peel a piece of the canvas off his palm, others who witnessed the accident said. 
 The railing is now gone, and the portrait, painted in 1910 by Augustus Goodyear Heaton, is being restored by Kenneth S. Moser, a private conservator in Manhattan. 
 Heaton, an academic painter and a Historical Society president, donated the work to the institution. He made a career of copying earlier portraits of famous Americans. This work is a copy of a Hosack portrait by the painter John Trumbull that hangs on the walls of New York Hospital. 
 Mr. Moser said the restoration would be routine. 
 ''It has a tear in the lower portion of the canvas,'' he said. Fortunately, Mr. Moser added, all of the pieces that came off the canvas were salvaged and delivered to him in a plastic bag. 
 His job chiefly involves realigning threads and using adhesive to attach them to the edges where the tears occurred. Mr. Moser will also have to fill in some of the missing paint, to match the surrounding color and gloss. 
 ''It's repairable,'' Mr. Moser said. 
 Jake Lynn, a spokesman for the Historical Society, said officials were hoping to get the portrait back on the walls of the show as soon as possible, and well before it closes on Feb. 28.

Feathers and Mirrors
 The seven-foot cylindrical structure covered with white feathers on Duarte Square, a triangular patch at the intersection of Canal Street and the Avenue of the Americas, may seem a bit odd. But the Romanian-born artist who created it can explain. 
 ''I'm trying to debate the issue of safety, displacement and identity, all issues that go hand-in-hand,'' the artist, Leonard Ursachi, said of ''Refuge,'' which was installed last weekend and will be on view through Dec. 17. The work is one of a four bunkerlike structures that Mr. Ursachi has made over the years. Three are in the United States, and one in Romania.
 ''My bunker projects, with their twin references to war and home, address the complexities inherent in the creation and maintenance of identity,'' Mr. Urasachi said. 
 The work is one of many coordinated by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. The artist covers the cost of fabricating and installing the work as well as insurance. The payoff is the opportunity to exhibit his art to a large audience with support from the city. 
 ''Refuge'' has no entrance, but rather two recessed sky-blue mirrors in which visitors can see their reflection as they approach the piece. It is fashioned from a thin layer of rustproof steel covered in plastic, to which the artist glued turkey feathers purchased from a plume company in Texas. Because it weighs only about 150 pounds, it is held down with 1,000-pound sandbags, Mr. Ursachi said. 
 Once the structure comes down, its fate is uncertain. But ''I've already had interest from museums,'' the artist said.

Raising Money in Boston
 The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, may be gloating. This week it announced that it had raised $245 million, or more than 55 percent, of the $425 million target for its fund-raising campaign. The money is going toward an ambitious building project designed by Foster & Partners, the London architects, that is scheduled for completion in 2009. Officials at the museum say the fund-raising effort is one of the most ambitious for any cultural institution outside New York and the largest of any arts institution in the Boston area. 
 ''In a time of profound recession in a very conservative town, it's amazing that we have been able to raise so much money,'' said Malcolm Rogers, the museum's director. He said that 51 gifts were of $1 million or more, and that the majority of the money had come from donors in the Boston area.

On an Island in Paris
 Francois Pinault, the luxury goods magnate who melded a passion for contemporary art with a keen business savvy when he bought Christie's in 1998, is moving ahead with plans to build the Francois Pinault Foundation for Contemporary Art, a 350,000-square-foot building designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando, on the Ile Seguin, an island in the Seine in Paris. It is to open in late 2007. 
 Mr. Pinault is not only about to break ground but has also already hired a director: Philippe Vergne, a senior curator at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. 
 The two met at the 2003 Venice Biennale and have been talking ever since. ''We have three years in front of us to build in every sense of the word, to invent a structure to promote art and culture in the 21st century,'' Mr. Vergne said. 
 He will remain at the Walker through April 2005, when it opens its expanded space, designed by the Swiss architects Herzog and de Meuron. He will travel back and forth between Paris and Minneapolis while organizing a traveling retrospective of Huang Yong Ping, the Chinese-born, Paris-based conceptual artist.

HEADLINE: There's a Lot Up the Sleeves Of Two Political Jokesters

BYLINE: By MANOHLA DARGIS

 BODY:
It isn't every movie that features a man in a gold lame bodysuit with a three-foot gilt phallus that would make Superman blush or maybe just reconsider the whole Lois Lane thing. Then again it's not every film that features the Yes Men, a coterie of anti-corporate activists who travel the world with sartorial flair, political ire and a prodigious sense of the absurd. Like the makeover mavens from ''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy,'' the Yes Men have a way of winning over strangers and commandeering drab rooms. As the golden appendage proves, they also know a little something about accessorizing. 
 Part performance piece, part political intervention, the unveiling of the appendage takes pride of place in the new nonfiction film ''The Yes Men,'' which opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Chris Smith, Dan Ollman and Sarah Price, the film brings together some of the Yes Men's more recent pranks with a fly-on-the-wall look at how these activists operate. Diverting if heavily padded, this is the newest addition to an increasingly crowded field of political nonfiction films and certainly the easiest viewing. 
 Like many recent documentaries, ''The Yes Men'' takes a sacrosanct approach to its subject, up to the point that it sometimes plays like a promotional video, so it's unlikely to rock your world or worry your sleep. Entertainment rules even when the ideological vibe is more Noam Chomsky than Donald Trump. Still, because leftists tend to be downers, what with their horror stories about hegemony, it's a relief that the Yes Men are guided more by the spirit of Abbie Hoffman than Mr. Chomsky. (They're partly financed by the sympathetic likes of the Herb Alpert Foundation.)
 The waggery becomes evident in the film when two of the Yes Men, Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno, show up in Tampere, Finland, for an August 2001 trade conference called ''Textiles of the Future.'' The Yes Men had been invited by conference organizers, who, on visiting the activists' Web site believed they were contacting the real World Trade Organization. The opening pages on both groups' Web sites look identical, and none of the Finnish organizers bothered to vet the phony W.T.O. or its representatives, one of whom had infiltrated a seminar on international trade in Salzburg, Austria, the year before. 
 (That prank isn't included in the documentary, but it's worth repeating what one of the Austrian organizers later wrote about one Dr. Andreas Bichlbauer, a k a Andy Bichlbaum: ''The essential thrust of his speech appeared to be that Italians have a lesser work ethic than the Dutch, that Americans would be better off auctioning their votes in the presidential election to the highest bidder and that the primary role of the W.T.O. was to create a one-world culture.'')
 The Salzburg stunt was reported in the press, including The New York Times, and prompted a response from the World Trade Organization that essentially boiled down to a representative's stating that the world body ''deplored'' the Yes Men. (In a magazine interview, Mr. Bichlbaum later responded that the Yes Men ''deplored'' the W.T.O. right back.) Happily for activists and for the documentary, the news seems never to have reached Finland.
 And so, Mr. Bichlbaum and Mr. Bonanno, armed with that shiny bodysuit and with a camera crew in tow, traveled to Finland to unleash their mischief. They may not have been mischievous enough. Remarkably, the conference attendees looked surprisingly unruffled by Mr. Bichlbaum's outre getup (including his three-foot ''Employee Visualization Appendage,'' with camera attached at the end) or his outlandishly funny take on slavery and the advantages of ''involuntary'' labor.
 Maybe Finnish executives are super-polite, the ultimate yes men and women. Or maybe the authentic World Trade Organization is so surreal that nobody notices when it's lampooned. If you're not up on multinational trade it is hard to know what to believe, because no one in ''The Yes Men'' really explains what's wrong with the trade body; it's simply a given that, like globalization, it stinks. That may be indeed the case, but it's too bad the filmmakers didn't work harder and assume less. During another intervention, one of the Yes Men announces that the World Trade Organization has decided to disband. The organization, he says, will ''eventually reintegrate as a new trade body whose charter will be to ensure that trade benefits the poor.'' For some, the irony here will be rich; for free-trade absolutists, though, it will probably just sound like W.T.O. business as usual.
 ''The Yes Men'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It contains some adult language and raucous humor.

THE YES MEN

Directed by Chris Smith, Dan Ollman and Sarah Price; edited by Mr. Ollman; produced by Mr. Smith and Ms. Price; released by United Artists. At the Landmark's Sunshine Cinema, 139-143 East Houston Street, East Village. Running time: 83 minutes. This film is rated R.

WITH: Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno.

HEADLINE: United Provides an Idea Of Worker Pension Losses

BYLINE: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
In a bankruptcy court yesterday, United Airlines described how a possible pension termination would affect its tens of thousands of employees and retirees, in a filing that seemed intended to both prepare and reassure them about an impending default. 
 In what it called an informational brief, the airline said that it did not want to play down the ''profound implications'' of such a step. But at the same time, United asserted, the consequences ''may not be as dire for most plan participants as they might fear.''
 United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, went on to describe how much various workers' benefits might be reduced as a result of the termination. The reductions are the result of limits on the government's pension-insurance coverage. The rules of the federal program are extremely complex, and United cautioned that its estimates were preliminary and subject to revision. 
 United also said it was committed to setting up replacement plans if it did ultimately terminate the existing plan. But the airline offered few details about what such plans would look like. 
 In general, the government frowns on company's defaulting on their ailing pension plans, and then, once freed from the burdens, setting up new pension plans. Any new retirement plan that United might offer would be carefully scrutinized by federal regulators. 
 Even for a company in distress, as United is, terminating an underfunded pension plan is a drastic and unusual step that can be taken only with the approval of a bankruptcy court.
 Congress made so-called distress terminations difficult in order to keep companies from abusing the federal pension-insurance program by dumping unwanted pension obligations onto the government. 
 United's steps toward a pension termination are being closely watched, not only by the airline's own employees and retirees, but by workers at other airlines and other sectors of the economy, who fear a similar fate may one day lie in store for them. 
 On reductions, United's 101-page brief confirmed the widely held expectation that its pilots' benefits were most at risk. Pilots earn larger pensions than any other group of workers, and larger than the maximum benefit insured by the government. 
 United said that just 44 percent of its active pilots could expect to receive their full benefits in case of a termination. The rest would suffer losses. On average, United said, its active pilots would lose about 39 percent of the value of their pensions upon retirement. Those already retired would fare better. 
 Flight attendants would lose much less. United's brief says that 99 percent of them would receive their entire earned benefits in a termination. 
 It cautioned, however, that they would get less if they retired early.
 A larger group of mechanics would experience reductions -- 38 percent, United said. But it said the reductions would be small in every case, with the average mechanic losing only 4 percent and ''no mechanic retiree experiencing more than a 20 percent reduction in benefits.''
 Salaried and management employees would have widely different outcomes depending on whether they were working or retired at the time of termination. Those still actively employed would receive only 51 percent of their pretermination benefits, United said. But retirees would be much less adversely affected, retaining 99 percent of their pensions, on average. 
 United also made calculations for its work force as a whole and predicted that current retirees would receive 90 percent of their benefits, on average. For current workers, the airline said, reductions ''would not be draconian and could be mitigated by retiring closer to age 65.''
 United also said it was ''firmly committed'' to supplementing the government's insurance with new retirement benefits. It did not describe the plan, but said it would try to make the benefits ''durable, affordable and competitive.'' It said it would work with its various unions on designing them.
 But United made clear that if it terminated its pension plan, it would not then try to recreate any kind of defined-benefits plan -- the type it now offers, which promised workers a predetermined benefit with a government guarantee. Instead, United said, it expected that subsequent retirement benefits would be in the form of 401(k) plans.

HEADLINE: The Face of Iraqi Democracy

 BODY:
Iraq's appointed leader, Ayad Allawi, put on an impressive performance yesterday in Washington. Addressing Congress and then holding a joint news conference with President Bush, he thanked America in the name of the Iraqi people for overthrowing Saddam Hussein. Challenging the news reports that Americans get daily, Mr. Allawi claimed that security is improving, economic reconstruction is progressing and democratic institutions are taking root. It was everything the Bush re-election campaign could have asked for. Unfortunately, most of it was wrong. 
 Until Iraq holds free elections, Mr. Allawi cannot claim to speak for more than the narrow coalition of exile parties that maneuvered his appointment as interim prime minister. Increasingly well-organized and deadly attacks are directed against American troops, foreign relief workers and Iraqi security recruits. Sunni towns like Falluja and Mosul and Shiite areas, including much of Baghdad, are gripped by insurgencies that American military analysts believe are nowhere near being overcome. Oil pipelines are attacked regularly, electricity supplies remain erratic, and foul drinking water breeds disease. 
 With the United Nations expressing doubts over whether Iraq will be secure enough to hold elections by January, American commanders are planning to launch an all-out offensive shortly after the November presidential elections here. They hope to secure enough Iraqi territory to permit a presentably nationwide vote. Meanwhile, the main exile-rooted parties behind Mr. Allawi seem intent on suppressing all real political competition. 
 Mr. Allawi spent most of the past quarter-century in exile. He got his start in politics as an enforcer for Saddam Hussein, but broke with the Baathists and was nearly murdered by Mr. Hussein's agents. He built a political base around a core of disaffected ex-Baathist officers -- and gained the backing of the Central Intelligence Agency, which supported him during the last decade or so of Mr. Hussein's rule. Since he was appointed interim prime minister in June, Mr. Allawi has not tried very hard to remake himself as a democrat. He has armed himself with the power to declare martial law and reinstated the death penalty, and he closed the Baghdad offices of Al Jazeera when it refused to adjust its editorial policies to his liking. His main appeal to Iraqis rests on the notion that he may be the only politician ruthless enough to hold the fragmenting country together. 
 The image Mr. Allawi was working hard to cultivate yesterday in Washington was very different. He wants to be seen as the firm but low-key leader of an emergent Iraqi democracy. He was occasionally compelling, but ultimately unconvincing, with contradictory messages that things are going well and that airing any evidence that things are not going well provides aid and comfort to terrorists. It's disturbing to see someone who presents himself as the future leader of a democracy begin by expressing doubts about the value of a free press and refusing to accept the importance of an honest and realistic discussion of what's happening in his country.

HEADLINE: Kerry Accuses President Of Misleading U.S. on Iraq

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON; David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Bangor, Me., for this article.

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Stepping up his efforts to put President Bush on the defensive over Iraq, Senator John Kerry said on Thursday that conditions there were so bad there that the elections planned for January were in jeopardy and that the president's assertions that things were improving did not match reality.
 Speaking just after Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq said at a joint session of Congress that the elections would go ahead on schedule, and just before Mr. Bush told a news conference that Iraq had made ''steady progress,'' Mr. Kerry suggested that the president was misleading the American people and stubbornly unwilling to change course. 
 ''The prime minister and the president are here obviously to put their best face on the policy,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''But the fact is that C.I.A. estimates, the reporting, the ground operations and the troops all tell a different story.''
 Mr. Kerry said he would do a better job of training Iraqis to provide security and rallying other nations to help. Mr. Bush's obstinacy in the face of mounting violence, he said, was endangering American troops and dimming the prospects for the Iraqis to establish a democratic government.
 ''I want democracy to take hold,'' Mr. Kerry said. But at the moment, he added, ''I think most people would tell you that the United States and the Iraqis have retreated from whole areas of Iraq. There are 'no go' zones in Iraq today. You can't hold an election in a 'no go' zone.''
 In his brief address here and in a question-and-answer session with reporters afterward, Mr. Kerry intensified his weeklong effort to shift the focus of the race from whether it was right to invade Iraq, a subject the White House has used to pillory him as inconsistent and unprincipled, to Mr. Bush's management of the war, a topic the Kerry campaign said would work to its advantage.
 ''These are miscalculations which are costing lives, costing America's reputation in the world,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''These are miscalculations of judgment. And that's what we hire a president for, is to exercise the right judgment. I think this president has exercised the wrong judgment from Day 1, and that's why we need a change.''
 Referring to Mr. Bush's two-day visit this week to the United Nations, which he also used to meet with the leaders of Japan, India and Pakistan, Mr. Kerry said the president had missed another opportunity to build international support for the United States in Iraq.
 ''The president skedaddled out of New York so quickly, he barely had time to talk to any leaders,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''We need a summit. We need to bring people to the table. We need to behave like we are at war and respect the lives of our soldiers that are being lost because we are at war. They deserve better leadership. They deserve a mission with a plan that can succeed.''
 The White House quickly hit back. In a speech Thursday in St. Joseph's, Mo., Vice President Dick Cheney said he was appalled at what he called Mr. Kerry's lack of respect for Mr. Allawi and suggested that Mr. Kerry was defeatist.
 ''John Kerry is trying to tear down all the good that has been accomplished,'' Mr. Cheney said, ''and his words are destructive to our effort in Iraq and in the global war on terror.'' 
 After careering from one strategy and one message to another for months, Mr. Kerry's campaign appears to have settled on taking the political battle directly to what the White House has viewed as Mr. Bush's greatest strength, his standing as commander in chief. Late on Thursday, the Kerry campaign released a new television commercial suggesting that only by electing a new president with a new approach will the United States be able to stabilize Iraq and move closer toward bringing the troops home. 
 ''Terrorists are pouring into the country,'' the commercial's narrator says of Iraq. ''Attacks on U.S. forces are increasing every month. A thousand American soldiers have died. We need a fresh start to fix the mess in Iraq.''
 His aides said Mr. Kerry intended to follow up on Friday with a speech in Philadelphia in which he would draw a distinction between Iraq and the battle against Islamic terrorism. Mr. Kerry's focus on Iraq was particularly striking on Thursday, which he started in Ohio, a crucial swing state in which job losses have made the economy a potent weapon for him against Mr. Bush. But in his lone public appearance of the day, at a firehouse here where he was accompanied by John Glenn, the former astronaut and senator, Mr. Kerry did not utter a single word about domestic issues. (In fact, Mr. Kerry uttered relatively few words about anything because of the lingering effects of a cold that left him hoarse on Wednesday and still raspy on Thursday. He canceled campaign appearances in Iowa.)
 Mr. Kerry's advisers said he was emphasizing Iraq and terrorism to reframe the way the two sides are fighting over foreign policy heading into the first presidential debate next Thursday. The first debate's subject is foreign policy.
 They said Mr. Kerry would return to domestic issues, but would do so using the same framework he is applying to Mr. Bush's handling of Iraq.
 ''Drawing these sharp contrasts with Bush on Iraq is very important because this is a fundamentally important issue,'' said Michael D. McCurry, the former press secretary to President Bill Clinton who is now advising Mr. Kerry. ''But the larger argument we're making here is that if you don't see the mistakes in policy and acknowledge them, you can't fix them. The country's not going to get any better if you can't wake up and see the error of your ways. And that is a pattern with George Bush.''
 Just a few hours after his Rose Garden news conference, Mr. Bush stepped up his attack on Mr. Kerry in a campaign event at the airport in Bangor, Me. It was critical, Mr. Bush said, ''not to wilt or waver or send mixed messages to the enemy.''
 As Mr. Bush spoke, his communications director, Dan Bartlett, said that Mr. Kerry's efforts to articulate a position on Iraq would not stand up to scrutiny, and that the Kerry campaign was on the defensive. 
 ''The line of scrimmage is that we're now on Kerry's 35'' yard line, Mr. Bartlett said. ''We are clearly playing on their turf.''
 He said that as a result, ''we will spend much time in Iowa, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin,'' lumping New Hampshire in with states that Al Gore won in 2000 and that Mr. Kerry needs to hold on to.


GRAPHIC: Photos: Senator John Kerry yesterday in Philadelphia with the boxing champion Bernard Hopkins. President Bush was with supporters in Bangor, Me. (Photo by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
 (Photo by Stephen Jaffe/Agence France-Presse-Getty Images)

HEADLINE: As Bull Market Nears a Birthday, Few Seem Ready to Celebrate

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
TWO years ago, gloom hung over stock markets around the world. The bear markets that began after the technology bubble burst in 2000 had grown worse after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The American stock market suffered its deepest plunge -- 49 percent from top to bottom -- since the Great Depression.
 But all that ended with a bang. Markets in most countries hit bottom on Oct. 9, 2002, and rallied sharply. A spring retrenchment sent some to new lows, but they then came roaring back. Now stocks around the world are generally trading for at least 40 percent more than they fetched at the 2002 lows. This week both the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Asian Development Bank released optimistic forecasts. 
 But with the second anniversary approaching, few seem ready to celebrate. The bull has been limping this year, with markets trading in narrow ranges after hitting highs in the spring. There is a sense, in Europe and America, that the world is out of control, with jobs moving away and governments unable to solve real problems.
 Unfortunately, stock market history indicates big gains may not be on the immediate horizon. The third years of bull markets are seldom a lot of fun, as Sam Stovall, the chief investment strategist at Standard & Poor's, notes. This is the 10th bull market since the end of World War II, using the definition that a bull market requires a 20 percent gain and continues until a decline of at least 20 percent begins, and in only two of the previous nine has the third year posted a gain of more than 10 percent. The average is a rise of less than 1 percent, and three bulls died in their third year.
 This bull market began with a surge that surprised a lot of pessimists, but over all it has been a bit subpar. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 33.7 percent in its first year, three percentage points below average, and 6.7 percent so far in its second, about half the average. 
 Then there is the presidential election cycle. Much Wall Street commentary assumes that the stock market will do better if President Bush gets a second term and worse if he is defeated, in part because of concerns that Senator John Kerry might roll back some tax cuts that have been particularly beneficial to investors.
 But history shows that since 1945, the stock market has risen in the first year of six of seven Democratic terms and fallen in the first year of six of the eight Republican ones. On average, Democrats produce gains of 14.3 percent in the S.&P. 500 while Republicans show losses of 2.4 percent. In no other year of presidential terms is there such a difference between the parties. 
 That could be coincidence, of course, but there are explanations that make sense. Democrats, who are almost always viewed with suspicion by Wall Street as they enter office, may be eager to stimulate the economy immediately. Republicans may be more willing to take recessions early in their terms, particularly if they are succeeding a Democrat. They can blame the predecessor for the downturn, as the Bush campaign has done this year, and hope that a good recovery will be under way before the next election.
 A recession started in the first year of office of every Republican president who replaced a Democrat since World War II -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, Richard M. Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush. By contrast, the last Democrat to have that happen after replacing a Republican was Woodrow Wilson in 1913.
 This year's election may yet turn on Iraq. But so far as the economy goes, President Bush has sought to follow in the footsteps of three presidents under whom recessions turned to recoveries in time to win second terms with ease. The tepid stock market this year illustrates how little enthusiasm this recovery is producing as the election nears.

HEADLINE: Summoning History as a Weapon Against the Iraq War

BYLINE: By CHARLES A. KUPCHAN. 
Charles A. Kupchan, professor of international affairs at Georgetown University and senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, is the author of ''The End of the American Era: U.S. Foreign Policy and the Geopolitics of the 21st Century.''

 BODY:

WAR AND THE AMERICAN PRESIDENCY
By Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.
160 pages. Norton. $23.95.

THE FOLLY OF EMPIRE
What George W. Bush Could Learn From Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson
By John B. Judis
245 pages. Scribner. $24.
 With the presidential election approaching, American bookstores are fully stocked with harsh assessments of the Bush administration's foreign policy. The historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and John B. Judis, a senior editor of The New Republic, have now contributed to the mix, offering books distinguished from the rest by their astute use of American history to illuminate the shortcomings in Washington's approach to global politics.
 Mr. Schlesinger's ''War and the American Presidency'' is a collection of historical reflections that deftly challenge the political and ideological foundations of President Bush's foreign policy. Mr. Schlesinger begins by tracing the roots of the administration's go-it-alone tendencies, noting that ''through most of its history, America has been stubbornly unilateralist in foreign relations.'' It took World War II and Franklin D. Roosevelt's tireless public diplomacy to persuade Americans to embrace allies and a centrist brand of international leadership, a new course that outlasted the cold war -- but not the Bush administration.
 ''Let no one doubt the political potency of the unilateralist resuscitation,'' Mr. Schlesinger asserts, strengthened as it is by the military primacy of the United States and the urge to strike preventively that has been prompted by 9/11. ''Military might is no substitute for friends and allies,'' he warns, ''nor is it a substitute for wisdom. It is a stimulus to vainglory -- and vainglory is self-defeating, as we Americans are learning the hard way,'' the country now ''eyeless in Iraq'' and saddled with ''a ghastly mess.''
 The politics of war and patriotism, Mr. Schlesinger contends, has vested the executive branch with more political power than intended by the founding fathers, not for the first time creating an ''imperial presidency'' insufficiently constrained by constitutional checks and balances. Attorney General John Ashcroft, armed with the Patriot Act, has overstepped his bounds, Mr. Schlesinger argues, imperiling civil liberties in a manner reminiscent of the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798, the Sedition Act of 1918 and the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II. In each of these cases, Mr. Schlesinger chides, ''we hate ourselves in the morning.''
 Mr. Schlesinger goes on to charge the Bush administration with exploiting the politics of fear and stifling wartime dissent by labeling it unpatriotic. Its success in doing so meant that ''no national debate preceded the Iraq war of a quality and seriousness that preceded most wars in American history.'' With its power unfettered both abroad and at home, Mr. Bush's imperial presidency has been free to pursue an imperial foreign policy.
 American history informs Mr. Schlesinger's indictment of the Bush administration, but it also instills his confidence in democracy's ''capacity for self-correction.'' Mr. Schlesinger predicts that the reckless adventurism will not last, noting that ''Americans are simply not competent imperialists, as demonstrated in Iraq in 2004.'' The country's ''own humane, pluralistic and tolerant ideals'' will ultimately undermine its imperial aspirations. In three concluding essays, Mr. Schlesinger dwells on the need to reinvigorate these ideals, again drawing on the lessons of history to caution against complacency and stress the importance of renewing America's democratic institutions and spirit.
 In ''The Folly of Empire,'' Mr. Judis explores the Bush administration's imperial impulse, drawing links to America's founding era and the country's self-perception as a ''city on the hill'' that would be an exemplar of liberal democracy for the world. During the 19th century the imperial urge accompanying this millennial vision made itself felt largely in North America, helping fuel westward expansion and the Indian wars. Beyond America's own hemisphere, the founding fathers and their immediate successors were adamant that the United States avoid entangling commitments.
 By the end of the 19th century, the country's growing economic and military might tempted its leaders with overseas empire, an offer taken up by President William McKinley in 1898. After successfully ousting Spanish forces from Cuba, the United States went on to colonize the Philippines and a host of other islands. Stoking the war fever and helping to lay the ideological foundations for empire was Theodore Roosevelt, McKinley's assistant secretary of the Navy and his successor as president. Roosevelt's belief in the racial supremacy of Anglo-Saxons, the importance of martial spirit and the country's civilizing mission abroad contributed to a new and muscular brand of American nationalism.
 The imperial fervor was short-lived. An insurgency in the Philippines made the United States occupation far more costly than expected. By his second term Roosevelt had come to see the Philippines as ''our heel of Achilles,'' and his enthusiasm for empire had given way to a more moderate and multilateralist brand of internationalism of the sort later championed by Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt.
 After his compelling account of the country's first flirtation with empire, Mr. Judis directs his fire at the Bush administration, persuasively arguing that it has revived the errant imperialism of the late 19th century. After the relatively easy victory in Afghanistan, he writes, President Bush and his advisers ''experienced the same rush of national power and the same illusion of omnipotence that the McKinley administration had experienced after the 'splendid little war' against Spain.'' Again misled, he says, by the naive assumption that the country's millennial mission could be achieved through force and occupation -- and backed by erroneous assessments of Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction and his links to Al Qaeda -- Washington guided the country into a colonial quagmire in Iraq, alienating allies and stirring up widespread anti-American sentiment. ''When America goes out alone in search of monsters to destroy,'' Mr. Judis warns, ''it can itself become the monster.''
 ''War and the American Presidency'' and ''The Folly of Empire'' both have a hurried feel to them, containing analysis that is at times cursory and claims that go unsubstantiated. Presumably, their authors were rushing to ensure publication before the November election. Nonetheless both volumes constitute valuable appraisals of the Bush presidency, bringing to bear the weight of United States history to make a convincing case that the administration has led the country woefully off course.

 John B. Judis (Photo by Chad Evans Wyatt)
