HEADLINE: The Airport As Flight Boutique

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: NORTH CASTLE 

 BODY:
GONE are the days when the Westchester County Airport operated from a ramshackle Quonset hut -- when lines snaked out the door and cars were parked at all angles on grassy embankments.
 In the past decade, since a sleek new terminal was built, the airport has taken on a well-nourished appearance, emerging as the kind of transportation center you would expect to find just outside New York City, in one of the richest counties in the country.
 It is, in short, a study in efficiency and good design -- from the meticulous landscaping at the entrance to the carefully laid out passenger screening areas. Its restaurant, the Skytop, even gets high marks from food critics. All of which would seem to make it a tempting alternative to the crowds and relative dilapidation of the region's other airports. 
 Why, then, has ridership fallen by 25 percent in the past few years, to a level not seen since before the multimillion-dollar makeover of 1995? Late last year, county officials were even forced to dip into a special airport revenue fund to make up an anticipated $850,000 shortfall in the current year's budget.
 Part of the drop can of course be explained by the dual impacts on air travel of the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks and the faltering economy. But commercial traffic at both John F. Kennedy International Airport and La Guardia Airport have since rebounded. Westchester has about 750,000 passengers a year -- compared with one million a year throughout the 1990's and into 2001.
 A big problem is cost. County officials acknowledge what anyone who has flown out of Westchester already knows: It's not cheap. Some travel agents put the airport's fares among the highest in the nation.
 Hinting at another factor potentially limiting business -- the need to keep the peace with the wealthy surrounding communities by reining in the air traffic -- Susan Tolchin, chief adviser to the county executive, Andrew J. Spano, called Westchester a ''boutique airport,'' adding: ''You're never going to have planes taking off and landing every five minutes. So right away that limits the amount of commercial aircraft, and when you have a smaller supply, you can charge more.''
 In a sampling of the views of both frequent and infrequent users of the airport, other negatives were cited as well: the lack of direct flights to popular destinations like Florida, for example, and the limited alternatives if a flight is canceled.
 ''If you miss a flight at La Guardia,'' said Andrew A. Beveridge, a longtime Yonkers resident, ''there's another flight in a half-hour to Boston or Washington, so you have many options.
 ''But if one little thing goes wrong at Westchester,'' added Mr. Beveridge, who teaches sociology at Queens College, ''you're on your way to another airport.''
 Westchester officials -- quick to point out that the county-owned airport operates without any taxpayer money -- do not seem terribly troubled by the decline in business. They are confident ridership will pick up. 
 ''Who knows what will happen a year from now if the economy zooms off?'' asked Lawrence C. Salley, commissioner of the Westchester County Department of Transportation, which oversees the site.
 Russ Gilfix of nearby Greenwich, Conn., was awaiting a flight to Florida recently. He had decided that morning to rush to the aid of his elderly mother, who was bracing for the arrival of Hurricane Frances. The $500 round-trip fare he bought wasn't exactly a bargain, but he said he didn't care about the price.
 ''In this case,'' he said, ''what was more important was being sure there was a flight I could make.'' 
 Mr. Gilfix, a 47-year-old financial adviser, said he rarely flew anywhere from Westchester, even though the 700-acre airport borders his town. (Slightly more than half of the passengers who fly out of Westchester live in Connecticut, airport officials say.)
 ''The few times I really checked the prices,'' he said, ''the least expensive flights didn't seem to be out of here. Certainly, convenience-wise, there's no comparison. Tell them to bring their prices in line.''
 A flight from Westchester can indeed run double or more that of a flight from J.F.K. or La Guardia to the same city on the same airline. But that tends to be truer the later you wait to book the seat. For instance, a reservation agent for Air Canada, which flies to Toronto from both Westchester and La Guardia, recently quoted prices for 14-day advance round-trip tickets from the two airports that were virtually identical: $184.85 from Westchester on an 18-seat propeller plane versus $183.35 from La Guardia on a 130-seat jet.
 But for flights leaving the next day, the airfares diverged sharply. The cost of a round-trip flight from Westchester to Toronto booked within 24 hours of departure was running a lofty $1,126 in early September, compared with $338 from La Guardia.
 Mr. Salley offered another example. Two years ago, his department sent two staff people to a conference in Chicago. Reserved a month in advance, the tickets cost $199 round trip each. But, he said, when a third employee decided to attend, the county tried to buy a seven-day advance ticket for a seat on the same jet, and the quote was $1,300. The employee stayed home.
 What Mr. Salley found strangest was his staffers' report that the plane was practically empty when it took off. Apparently, he concluded, the airline would rather fly the plane with nobody on it than get the $300.
 For many passengers, though, convenience trumps cost no matter what. Being able to avoid the slog to La Guardia and J.F.K., with their potential for disastrous traffic tie-ups, is priceless, these travelers say. Besides, most of the passengers flying into and out of Westchester are not paying the fares anyway. Their companies are.
 ''Everybody I know would rather fly here,'' said Jonathan Moore, 37, a marketing director for Unilever, who lives and works in Chicago and flies east six times a year for meetings in Greenwich.
 Mr. Moore found some fault with the airport, calling the Skytop restaurant ''a bit soulless'' and the flight reliability ''patchy.'' (That patchiness was evidenced by the cancellation of his 4:20 flight to Chicago.) But in general, he said, touching down just minutes away from his business meetings in Connecticut ''sure beats driving up from La Guardia.'' 
 Another traveler, Ned Moore (who is no relation) agreed. ''This is just so convenient,'' said Mr. Moore, a Danbury resident who had arrived to pick up his son after a flight from San Diego. ''We make it a point to use it if we can.''
 An adjunct professor of education at Western Connecticut State University, Mr. Moore well remembers when the airport was a jarringly shabby fixture in an otherwise ship-shape county.
 ''It used to be like a little barn, and you were walking through the mud,'' he said. ''I once heard someone make a remark one rainy night that it's hard to believe you're in Westchester County. It feels like a third-world country.''
 But sitting in the light-filled lobby, with its soothing gray tones and chic geometric lines, he had nothing but praise for the new terminal, which was humming with activity during a recent afternoon rush. ''Now it's very modern, bright and efficient,'' he said. ''You get a good feeling being here. It looks professional.''
 Some passengers insist that they have discovered competitive prices by patiently searching the Internet. ''I have found some great fares,'' said Aruna Moidu of Ridgefield, Conn., who was waiting for her husband to arrive from Minneapolis. ''It's just a question of luck.''
 Luck is the operative word. 
 ''I haven't been able to figure it out,'' said Mr. Salley, referring to the hit-or-miss quality of comparison airfare shopping in the region. 
 Occasionally, Westchester turns out to be cheaper. For example, a Continental Airlines ticket agent quoted the exact same price to Cleveland -- $580 for a one-way fare within seven days -- from either Westchester County Airport or La Guardia . But a 14-day advance ticket from Westchester to Cleveland was just $144 round trip, compared with $164 from La Guardia.
 In some respects, the county is forever juggling two seemingly contrary goals: keeping the airport as busy as possible to ensure its economic viability, while maintaining good relations with the affluent municipalities that surround it. The airport straddles the towns of North Castle and New Castle, as well as the village of Rye Brook.
 With flights down, it has been easier to control noise pollution and ground-water runoff -- although the 25 percent drop in passengers has not translated neatly into a corresponding drop in the number of flights. ''It's just that there are fewer people on the aircraft,'' Mr. Salley said.
 On Tuesday, the county announced that the airport had recently been certified by the International Organization for Standardization. The group, which is based in Geneva, Switzerland, has developed a set of internationally recognized standards for environmental stewardship, according to county officials, and Westchester is only the third airport in the nation to have met them.
 The county has 20 noise monitors scattered in communities surrounding the airport, and its Web site allows neighbors to identify loud airplanes by plugging in the time and date of the flight. 
 There is in fact one neighbor, whose house sits under a helicopter route to the airport in Harrison, who continues to make 30 to 40 complaints a month. ''They have us on speed-dial,'' Mr. Salley said grimly.
 For 20 years, the airport has sought the cooperation of the airlines to help keep the peace.
 One of its methods is a county policy called the Voluntary Restraint From Flying. The policy asks pilots not to take off and land between midnight and 6:30 a.m. 
 Four of the dozen commercial airlines at the airport, however, do take off somewhat earlier than 6:30, arguing that they must connect passengers to flights leaving from their hub airports.
 Then there is the Terminal Capacity Agreement, in which the county and the airlines restrict to four the number of takeoffs or landings every half-hour, and to 240 the number of passengers using the airport every half-hour. Two weeks ago, Mr. Spano signed a law that codifies those restrictions.
 With ridership as far off as it is, the airlines have had no trouble keeping within those limits.
 The county is feeling the fallout from the drop in commercial ridership, which makes up just 25 percent of all Westchester Airport flights. (Small private planes, corporate jets and charter planes account for the lion's share of activity.) Fees paid to the county from ticket sales, car rentals, concessions, ground handling and landings are all down.
 ''Certainly the decline in that passenger ridership has a negative effect on other activities at the airport,'' Mr. Salley said. ''It's something that we'll continue to monitor.''
 At the same time, since Sept. 11, 2001, the cost of securing the airport has skyrocketed. The county estimates that it now spends $5.1 million a year on airport security, up from $1.4 million before the terror attacks. 
 County officials take comfort in a sizable financial cushion: the airport's special revenue fund -- which, thanks to years of surpluses, has grown to $11.5 million. ''The bottom line is we have a huge reserve,'' Ms. Tolchin said.
 Whether passengers will start streaming back to Westchester County Airport if the economy leaps forward remains to be seen. Experts say that a number of changes in the airline industry and the corporate world might turn out to be more structural than fleeting.
 The rise of discount airlines, particularly Jet Blue, has fueled most of the growth at J.F.K., according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Those airlines may have permanently altered the notion of what constitutes a reasonable airfare, particularly among leisure travelers.
 ''We only have one discount airline -- Independence Air,'' said Mr. Salley, adding that the Terminal Capacity Agreement meant limited options for airlines in terms of flying times.
 Some travel agents also question whether business travel will ever return to pre-Sept. 11, 2001, levels.
 ''Westchester is a businessman's airport,'' said Barbara Herrott, president of Travel Exchange in Stamford, Conn. ''Post 9/11, many, many companies leave it to the discretion of their employees whether they want to make the trip, and Web conferencing has also taken away that travel.''
 And while many extol Westchester airport's convenience in terms of its proximity to home or office, a large segment of the flying public seems to value a direct, hassle-free journey to a final destination even more than a quick hop to the airport.
 Michael R. Edelman, a lawyer in White Plains and a Republican commentator for a cable television channel in Westchester, said he would pay a premium to fly directly from Westchester to Palm Beach, where he owns a vacation house.
 ''Who wants to go through another city to get to Florida?'' Mr. Edelman asked. ''It makes it a five-hour affair instead of a 2-hour-and-15-minute affair. If they offered direct flights to Palm Beach, I bet you their business would triple, especially in the winter.''
 Others believe the airport is poised for a comeback should prosperous times return. ''It has all the attributes -- all the good attributes -- of a small Midwestern airport,'' said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat who represents Westchester. ''It's not overly crowded. You don't get huge delays on the luggage. 
 ''It's sort of undiscovered.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: While passenger numbers since 9/11 have rebounded at La Guardia and Kennedy, Westchester's are still 25 percent lower than they were before the terror attacks. (Photo by Susan Stava for The New York Times)(pg. 1)
Despite its sleek design and functionality, the county airport rarely seems as bustling as its counterparts in the region. But Lawrence C. Salley, commissioner of the County Department of Transportation, is not overly concerned about the numbers. ''Who knows what will happen a year from now if the economy zooms off?'' he said. SECTION: Section 5; Column 1; Travel Desk; FALL/WINTER CRUISES; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 2074 words

HEADLINE: For Discounts, Ebb Tide

BYLINE: By SUSAN STELLIN. 
E-mail: stellin@nytimes.com

 BODY:
DURING a recent cruise along Inside Passage of Alaska, polite conversation ran the gamut from ''What did you do in port today?'' to ''What are you going to have, the halibut or the prime rib?''
 But the on-board banter also turned toward topics Miss Manners probably wouldn't condone: the upcoming election and the perhaps equally volatile question, ''So, how much did you pay for this trip?''
 Having decided on a seven-day cruise a month before sailing, I felt pretty smug about a last-minute special I got through a discount broker, Cruises-N-More: $2,709 for a cabin for two, with ocean view, on the lowest passenger deck of the Ryndam, a Holland America ship, which included air fare for two people from San Francisco and Grand Rapids, Mich. (flying into Vancouver and returning from Anchorage). It turned out a couple at our dinner table bought through the same agency a week later and paid virtually the same price (the only difference was the taxes on the air fare, since we came from different airports).
 But when I mentioned that price to another passenger, Debbie Roth, a teacher from Trumbull, Conn., it became apparent that not everyone got such a deal. ''Don't tell my husband that,'' she said. ''It'll ruin his trip.'' 
 That's just the reaction some cruise lines are hoping to avoid, with new policies designed to rein in the deep discounts cruise wholesalers have been offering in recent years. Some of this rock-bottom pricing was in response to the travel downturn following the Sept. 11 attacks, when the cruise lines themselves slashed prices to fill their ships. 
 But it's also due to a practice known as rebating, whereby discount brokers buy a block of cabins and share a portion of their commission with customers, enabling the discounters to sell cabins for lower prices than the cruise line itself or full-service travel agents. (Typically, the discount sellers do much less hand-holding -- a tradeoff for the savings you get.) 
 But now that travel has rebounded, particularly in the cruise industry, some cruise lines have announced changes in their pricing policies over the summer that aim to regain control over cabin prices. 
 In early August, Carnival Cruise Lines announced that beginning Jan. 1, any travel agency that advertised rates not approved by Carnival might receive a reduced commission or potentially be banned from selling its cruises. However, this policy applies only to Carnival Cruise Lines, not the other brands owned by Carnival Corporation, including Holland America.
 ''We're taking action to try to ensure consistency in advertised pricing,'' said Jennifer de la Cruz, a Carnival spokeswoman. ''Whether you're on a cruise or a land package, nobody likes to find out that the person next to them paid a better price.''
 Around the same time, Royal Caribbean International, which also owns Celebrity Cruises, advised travel agents that effective Aug. 16, any agency that advertises or sells a Royal Caribbean or Celebrity cruise for a nonpublished price would be penalized by reductions in commissions or other support from the cruise line. 
 ''We do not want a situation whereby any particular agency, for whatever reason, would be able to advertise a lower price for any sailing,'' said Jack L. Williams, the company's president.
 What impact these announcements will have on the industry is still up in the air, as travel agencies figure out what they can and cannot do under the new rules. For instance, Royal Caribbean's policy seems to be more restrictive, not only preventing agencies from advertising lower prices but also barring them from selling cruises below its own published rates. In other words, travel agencies can't toe the line in their advertising, then offer discounted rates once a customer calls for a quote and asks (wink, wink) if that's really, truly the best rate available. And it is also not clear yet whether other cruise lines will follow Carnival's lead. (Rose Abello, a spokeswoman for Holland America, said the company was watching what other cruise lines were doing but had not made any decision about following suit.) 
 ''We don't really know what's going to happen yet,'' said Jeffrey Kivet, co-owner of Cruise Value Center in East Brunswick, N.J., a cruise wholesaler with discount practices that will definitely be affected by the new policies. Even so, Mr. Kivet said, ''There will be ways to be creative, as long as you're not causing disruption in the advertising.''
 He said customers can typically save 9 to 14 percent off the cruise lines' published prices by buying through his agency. But even under the new policies, he said, he will still be able to offer discounts on packages that include air fare or a land tour before or after the cruise. But for the basic cruise price -- at least on Carnival, Royal Caribbean and Celebrity -- Mr. Kivet said: ''We're all going to have the same price. There's not going to be much additional discounting.'' 
 But the new policies don't mean that passengers will all pay the same price, even for the same size cabin with the same view (or lack thereof). Aside from the discounts offered by some agencies, prices for a cruise cabin vary depending on a number of factors: the size of the cabin, whether it has a window or a balcony, which deck you are on (higher decks are usually more expensive) and whether you're toward the front or rear of the ship (which cost less than cabins in the middle, generally a more stable area of the ship). The price is also affected by how far in advance a trip is booked. 
 In the Roths' case, they paid more for several reasons: they bought directly from the cruise line, Holland America; their cabin was on a higher deck and closer to the middle of the ship (though I would argue ours had a better view: we looked directly at the water, whereas their view included people strolling around the promenade deck), and they booked their trip in April, before last-minute sales kicked in. (For the record, they paid $3,476, not including air fare, but then received a $250 credit from Holland America for on-board expenses after they complained about seeing cheaper prices advertised elsewhere.)
 Although Mr. Roth, also a teacher, said he knew he might have saved money by waiting until the last minute, he felt it was worth paying a bit extra to have their summer vacation plans settled. (Even so, during our conversations on board and after the cruise, he insisted I not tell him what I paid, lest buyer's remorse mar an otherwise pleasant trip.) And with ships once again filling up, most cruise sellers expect 11th-hour deals to be less prevalent in the future, with the best discounts given to early birds instead. 
 Beyond the price of the cruise cabin itself, there are lots of other expenses that affect a trip's bill. Some agencies advertise prices that include port charges and taxes; others don't. So be sure to ask when comparing quotes for the same ship. Prices are also quoted both with and without air fare and bus transfers to get from the airport to the ship; you can sometimes save money by purchasing your own air fare, but if your flight is delayed, it's your responsibility to catch up to the ship. (If you buy air fare through the cruise line, it's their worry.)
 And once you're on board, there are plenty of expenses that usually cost extra: soft drinks, liquor, spa treatments, laundry, Internet access, tips (about $10 a day, per person), photos taken by the ship's photographer and, most of all, shore excursions, which can range from a $50 city tour to a $350 floatplane ride or fishing trip.
 ''The percent of cruise line profit that's coming from on-board spending is higher than ever,'' said Art Sbarsky, consumer affairs columnist for CruiseMates.com, which offers advice for first-timers and experts. Mr. Sbarsky advises passengers to budget a third of the cost of their cruise price for additional expenses -- more if you've got a heavy hand at the slot machine or are easily swayed by the bartender.
 Of course, you can save money by exploring port towns on your own, or booking excursions directly with tour companies once you dock instead of through the ship. But there's something about the cruise lines' cashless on-board environment that makes it all too easy to sign charge slips with abandon.
 Indeed, it's so easy that someone in another cabin managed to charge a couple of drink bills at the casino to our account -- an honest mistake, it turned out (our cabin numbers were similar). Still, that's another way to save money: check your bill carefully before you debark.

Finding help online and in print

Advice
 CruiseMates.com: A great site for information about cruising, including message boards, ship reviews, industry news and advice for first-timers, families and solo travelers.
 CruiseCritic.com: Another resource that can help you figure out which cruise line suits your style and where various ships are sailing, plus message boards with discussions on topics like saving money and choosing a cabin.
 ''Econoguide Cruises 2004,'' by Corey Sandler (The Globe Pequot Press, 2004, $17.95): A guide to choosing and buying a cruise, with ship reviews, money-saving tips and an overview of cruise culture, like dinner options, on-board entertainment and recommended attire.

Discounters
 CruiseCompete.com: You can specify a destination, cruise line and ship, and participating travel agencies post the lowest price they have available (you get an e-mail message when a new bid appears). 
 Cruises-N-More.com: Don't expect lots of hand-holding from this site -- or any other discounter -- but if you know which cruise you want, you can save money by buying from a wholesaler.
 MyCruiseValue.com: Also known as the Cruise Value Center, the site's busy front page can be overwhelming, but the company offers attractive discounts to those who already have a ship in mind.
 Other wholesalers: Cruise.com, CruiseDirect.com, Cruise411.com. SUSAN STELLIN

Storm warnings
 Anyone who books a cruise to the Caribbean during hurricane season is taking a chance that the ship may have to be rerouted because of high seas and strong winds. This year, those late-summer bookings have turned out to be a particularly bad bet.
 Hurricanes Charley, Frances and Ivan have wreaked havoc on Caribbean sailings, forcing at least a half-dozen cruises to be canceled as of early last week, while dozens of others have sailed with modified itineraries. That has meant visiting ports other than those scheduled to steer clear of bad weather or shortening some cruises, while some were actually lengthened waiting for Florida ports to reopen. 
 ''Up until this year, I used to tell people it never happens,'' said Jennifer de la Cruz, a spokeswoman for Carnival Cruise Lines. ''Only once in the company's history had we canceled a cruise because of a hurricane.'' In recent weeks, Carnival canceled three cruises, including a four-day Bahamas cruise set to leave Port Canaveral on Sept. 5, when Frances was coming through, and had to modify the itineraries of dozens of others.
 Ms. de la Cruz said the company offered full refunds to customers on canceled cruises. Passengers on shortened cruises were offered partial refunds, shipboard credits or discounts on a future cruise, depending on how drastically the itinerary was changed. In some cases, they were also given the option to cancel and get credit for a future cruise or a full refund.
 Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines also canceled three cruises and modified itineraries for at least 20 others. Michael Sheehan, a company spokesman, said passengers on canceled cruises were offered a full refund, while those on shortened cruises received $250 to $500 per stateroom toward onboard spending (depending on how many days were missed) and 50 percent off a future cruise.
 Julie Benson, a spokeswoman for Princess Cruises, said the company shortened one Caribbean cruise and gave passengers the choice of canceling with a full refund or future cruise credit. ''If they decided to go ahead and come aboard, we refunded 50 percent of their cruise fare, plus they received an onboard credit of $100,'' she said.
 Cruise lines usually offer full refunds when they cancel a sailing but reserve the right to skip a port or change course. If you had made your own air or shore arrangements, you may be responsible for ticket-change fees or excursions you've paid for, though cruise lines may reimburse customers for airline fees. SUSAN STELLIN

HEADLINE: A Crash Test For Indian Point?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re Indian Point (letters, Sept. 19) and all nuclear power plants, has our government ever conducted an actual crash test? 
 Considering the price for not knowing the actual capability of the concrete dome to withstand the impact of an airliner, I would assume the costs for building a mock dome and utilizing a remote-controlled retired airliner may indeed prove more economical and prudent. 
 As far as I know, the closest test was completed in the 1960's using an F-105 single-engine fighter. The fighter was launched into a concrete wall of the same material and thickness of those surrounding a nuclear reactor. But the aircraft was about one-tenth the weight and mass of a large airliner (and carrying a fraction of the fuel), and the wall was just a wall, not a dome anchored securely to the ground.
 With the memory of the World Trade Center's assumed ability to withstand the impact of an airliner, New York should consider spearheading a campaign for real-world testing.

Larry Mussman
Lake Worth, Fla.

The writer is an airline pilot.

HEADLINE: Social Security: Paths and Perils

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 ''How Not to Save Social Security'' (''The Big Issues'' series, editorial, Sept. 23) makes cogent arguments against the privatization of Social Security, but it should also be pointed out that a key economic justification for private retirement accounts, namely the increase in national savings, does not hold water. 
 Every dollar diverted to private accounts increases the federal deficit, and as first-year economic students are taught, that decreases national savings. 
 The hope that private investment accounts will fully offset this loss is a dream. Overwhelmingly, money invested in the stock market either is withdrawn by sellers of stock to be spent or remains in the stock market, often to finance consumption by shareholders through additional borrowing. 
 In the United States, very little investment in plant and equipment is provided by the sale of stock. In fact, for the last five years, there have been more buybacks of stock by corporations than new issues. Most stock market activity is simply between shareholders. 
 One then must ask why the Bush administration insists on subsidizing stock market purchases with federal debt. We suspect that the true goal is eventually to end Social Security.

Charles J. Zwick
Peter A. Lewis
New York, Sept. 23, 2004

The writers were, respectively, director and assistant director of the United States Bureau of the Budget under President Lyndon B. Johnson.

HEADLINE: Social Security: Paths and Perils

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Younger workers who are tempted by the Bush administration's dangling carrot of higher benefits if payroll taxes are diverted into the stock market had better look down before they grab it. 
 For decades, Social Security has achieved what it was designed to do: maintain a solid, stable economic floor that no eligible worker or family could fall through. 
 If President Bush's proposal to privatize Social Security is adopted, look out below!

Connie Gruen
Yardley, Pa., Sept. 23, 2004

HEADLINE: Honolulu

BYLINE: By JOCELYN FUJII. 
JOCELYN FUJII is a writer who lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
With Hawaii's economy, tourism and employment as healthy as they have ever been in recent memory, spirits are soaring and wine is flowing in Honolulu. New wine bars and restaurants, a booming downtown arts scene and beaches -- spared their summer throngs -- beckon. 
 In the newly confident Honolulu, the post-9/11 downturn has given way to a redefining of Waikiki as a resort that is as much for pedestrians as for surfers. After months of construction along the Ala Wai Canal in Waikiki, pedestrians will soon be sauntering on a newly green promenade brightened by flowers and shaded by coconut trees. 
 Pedestrians rule in downtown Honolulu, too, where, on the first Friday of the month, art lovers and the pau hana (after-work) crowd revel in music that spills onto the streets. 
 Gardens around the island are equally energized. Forty-five minutes away from the urban core, the Waimea Valley Audubon Center is the new diva of the North Shore, restored from years of neglect into a gem of a nature center by the National Audubon Society in partnership with the City and County of Honolulu. Across the road, beachgoers enjoy the turquoise water and fleeting calmness of Waimea Bay, deceptively glassy in the summer and fall but with huge waves in the winter.
 Nature and culture are equally at home in Hawaii's capital, where the pleasures of the season range from top-drawer ancient hula to the Harlem Gospel Choir.

Events
 The Louis Vuitton Hawaii International Film Festival, (808) 528-4433, www.hiff.org, runs Oct. 21 to 31 at Dole Cannery Theaters, 650 Iwilei Road, with selected films at the Doris Duke Theater at the Honolulu Academy of Arts, 900 South Beretania Street, and Hawaii Theater Center, 1130 Bethel Street. More than 100 films, featuring cross-cultural themes, are scheduled, starting with ''Clean,'' a French-American-Canadian-British production starring Maggie Cheung and Nick Nolte, at 8 p.m. Oct. 21 in the Hawaii Theater Center ($15). For the rest of the festival, tickets, $7 to $8, go on sale Oct. 5.
 Exhibitions at the Contemporary Museum at First Hawaiian Center, 999 Bishop Street, (808) 526-1322, feature the wood vessels of Robert Hamada, the dean of island wood-turners; large acrylics of Hawaiian women by Yvonne Cheng, and pastels by Margaret Ezekiel. It runs through Jan. 25. Closed weekends.
 The gallery is part of a self-guided downtown gallery walk (maps available at most downtown galleries) that reaches a crescendo on the first Friday of each month. Galleries and shops stay open late, and a self-guided art tour passes dim sum restaurants, Chinese herb and acupuncture shops and historic bluestone buildings as it leads the way to the hot spots of Honolulu's art world. The ARTS at Marks Garage, a gallery and performance space at 1159 Nuuanu Avenue, (808) 521-2903, is the unofficial nexus of First Friday.
 Built in 1922, the Hawaii Theater Center, 1130 Bethel Street, (808) 528-0506, www.hawaiitheatre.com, lights up its newly renovated Art Deco marquee at 8 p.m. Nov. 5 as part of First Friday. The theater's October program includes the hula and chant master Manu Boyd's annual hula and music concert at 7:30 p.m. Oct. 17 (tickets $20 to $35), featuring his acclaimed hula halau (school); guest performers include Hookena, Mr. Boyd's contemporary Hawaiian group, and Kainani Kahaunaele, an award-winning singer. At 7:30 p.m. Oct. 30, the Harlem Gospel Choir ($10 to $35) takes the stage. 
 Across town in Manoa Valley, at the Orvis Auditorium of the University of Hawaii, 2411 Dole Street, (808) 944-2697, the Tokyo String Quartet inaugurates the silver anniversary of the Honolulu Chamber Music Series on Oct. 16 with a program of Haydn, Zemlinsky and Dvorak at 7:30 p.m. Tickets, from etickethawaii.com, are $24. 

Sightseeing
 A spectacular opportunity awaits nature lovers downtown at Foster Botanical Garden, 50 North Vineyard Boulevard; (808) 522-7060. In the 14-acre oasis, originally planted in the 1850's, orchids and palms abound and cycads from the days of dinosaurs thrive in a glen. The tropical plant collection is one of the largest in the United States, but these days the rare talipot palm is the star. Thirty-seven years old and 30 feet tall, the palm has sprouted an antlerlike inflorescence that will reach 20 to 30 feet and bear millions of flowers and tens of thousands of nuts over the coming months. Only once in its life does the talipot achieve this, and it slowly dies afterward. Admission $5.
 The drive along the Kaiwi coast of Oahu to the island's easternmost point is an Oahu highlight, with views of Koko Crater and the ocean as Kalanianaole Highway curls along the jagged lava coastline. On a clear day you can see Molokai and Lanai across the channel, and sometimes Haleakala, the 10,000-foot mountain giant on far-off Maui. 
 At the easternmost stretch, about a half-mile past the Hawaii Kai Golf Course, a gate marks the starting point for a two-mile hike to the Makapuu Lighthouse. The ocean views make this walk notable. The lighthouse, built in 1909 and automated in 1974, sits above Makapuu Beach. Seabirds circle the cliffs and tiny offshore islands. Makapuu is a prime spot to view some of the nearly 40 species of migratory shorebirds that begin arriving in September. 
 Some of these shorebirds can also be seen at the Waimea Valley Audubon Center, 59-864 Kamehameha Highway, (808) 638-9199, about an hour from Honolulu. Until the Audubon Society took over in 2003, the area, with theme park features like cliff divers, was in a state of disrepair. Today, Audubon manages 500 of the 1,875 acres, propagating endangered and indigenous species and maintaining 35 gardens and cultural exhibits. At the end of a paved path, Wai Hi, a 45-foot waterfall, soothes all the senses. Admission is $8; open daily. Bug spray recommended. 

Where to Stay
 In its 40th anniversary year, the popular New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel, 2863 Kalakaua Avenue, (800) 356-8264, fax (808) 922-9404, www.kaimana.com, offers a $40 discount on some rates, available until Dec. 15. The 124-room hotel is near Diamond Head, across from Kapiolani Park, on Sans Souci and Kaimana Beach. An ocean-front room for two is $300, but a Diamond Head junior suite costs $215. Ask for a room number ending in 17 (517 and 617 in particular) to get an ocean-front room with a wraparound lanai and million-dollar views; rooms ending in 21 are almost as good. 
 With its Hawaiian music and new spa and the opening of a seafood restaurant and steak house, the Waikiki Beach Marriott Resort and Spa, 2552 Kalakaua Avenue, (800) 367-5370, fax (808) 921-5255, www.marriottwaikiki.com, is broadening its appeal. It's still an impersonal 1,310-room behemoth, but its new Spa Olakino hits the right notes in ambience and use of Hawaiian ingredients. Genoa Keawe, Hawaiian falsetto singer extraordinaire, performs poolside on Thursday nights; no cover charge. Though room rates are listed as $320 to $490, they often go for much less; city-view rooms were recently $179 and ocean deluxe rooms, $299. 
 The Asian-sleek Bamboo, 2425 Kuhio Avenue, (808) 922-7777, fax (808) 922-9473, www.aquabamboo.com, opened in late 2001 as a boutique hotel. Drawn by the rates, style and location -- two blocks from Waikiki Beach -- guests seem undeterred by noise of the sidewalk and street improvements being made to Kuhio Avenue. The 93 rooms are spacious, with black lacquer accents and white linens, glass showers, and multiple lanais in the higher categories. A deluxe studio has a kitchen with a refrigerator, and teak chairs on the lanai, for $195. Rates are $155 to $850. On a weekly stay at the $195 rate, two nights are free.
 Budget: Around the corner from Bamboo, the Royal Grove Hotel, 151 Uluniu Avenue, (808) 923-7691, fax (808) 922-7508, www.royalgrovehotel.com, is a Waikiki institution, kitschy, affordable and pink like the Royal Hawaiian. There are fresh flowers and fruit on the counter, surfboards in the lobby and a small pool with a piano nearby. The old Makai wing has no air-conditioning, so the main Makai wing is a better bet. The standard rooms in the main wing, at $60 or $370 a week, are clean and carpeted, with TV and lanai, double and single beds, rattan chairs, a stove and a small refrigerator. The hotel is two blocks from the beach. 
 Luxury: The Halekulani, (800) 367-2343, fax (808) 931-5065, 2199 Kalia Road, Waikiki, www.halekulani.com, is celebrating its 20th anniversary. The 155-room hotel is on the ocean, with prime Diamond Head views (visible from some of its bathtubs, too), nightly hula at the poolside restaurant, and two elegant restaurants. The rooms, in their signature pale blue and off-white, cost $325 to $540, and the service sets the standard.
 Country comfort is the theme of the 443-room Turtle Bay Resort, (800) 203-3650, fax (808) 293-9147, www.turtlebayresort.com, which offers a North Shore special Oct. 3 to Dec. 20 with oceanfront deluxe rooms for $295 and oceanfront premium rooms, $262. The lobby and some rooms have ocean and Turtle Bay views and there are two golf courses plus oceanfront hiking trails. From the expensive ($650 a night) new ground-floor cottages, you can often see turtles. Rooms have plush white comforters and sage-green walls.

Where to Eat
 Open since July, Vino wine bar, the hot newcomer on Honolulu's Restaurant Row at 500 Ala Moana Boulevard, (808) 536-6286, serves some excellent, affordable wines to match the tapas-style Italian fare: plump shrimp in roasted garlic butter, fresh and modestly fiery house-made ravioli, and seared foie gras in a decadent fig reduction. Scenes of Tuscan vineyards are painted on the walls. Dinner and wine for two, $70. Open for dinner Wednesday to Saturday. 
 Bouillabaisse lovers are heading for Petite Garlic, at 2238 Lauula Street in Waikiki, (808) 922-2221, serving the best spinach salad and fried garlic in town and a five-star bouillabaisse for under $15. Casual, open-air and pleasingly bohemian, it's tucked away in an alley. Dinner for two, about $50. Dinner nightly. 
 A new restaurant in Waikiki, Hula Grill Waikiki, 2335 Kalakaua Avenue, (808) 923-4852, is open to the ocean with Diamond Head and sunset views. The food is fine, especially the fresh opakapaka (a white-meat fish) and appetizers -- quesadillas of Big Island goat cheese, or scallop-lobster pot stickers -- but go as much for the kitsch and plantation atmosphere (and for the Baked Hawaiian, a pineapple-shaped fantasy of meringue, ice cream and pineapple upside-down cake). Open daily for breakfast and dinner, it's in the Outrigger Waikiki on the Beach. Dinner for two, about $70.
 At the opposite end of the design spectrum, Kai, 1427 Makaloa Street, (808) 944-1555, near Ala Moana shopping center, is all sleek steel and nouveau-Tokyo style, with excellent homemade tofu, grilled Kahuku shrimp, and eggplant with a pork wrap. Comfort foods abound -- rice steamed with fish and vegetables or in a delicate Kyoto-style broth. Dinner for two, about $70. Dinner nightly except Monday.
 Casablanca comes to Kahala at Cabanas Seaside Grill, in the Kahala Mandarin Oriental Hawaii, 5000 Kahala Avenue; (808) 739-8888. Guests enjoy seafood and grilled specialties under dreamy white tents a few feet from the sand. Seafood shines here, as in the moi (threadfish) and other fresh fish simmered whole in lobster stock and grilled. The atmosphere is casually luxe, with the pool on one side and the ocean on the other, and dishes are meant to be shared. Dinner for two, about $120.

 CORRECTION:
The What's Doing column on Sept. 26, about Honolulu, referred imprecisely to the age of the Halekulani Hotel. While the present owners are celebrating the 20th anniversary of the rebuilt resort, a hotel with that name has been operating on the site since 1917.

HEADLINE: The Price of Admission Is on the Rise

BYLINE: By HARLAN J. LEVY

 BODY:
PARENTS of Connecticut college underclassmen looking forward to the various parents weekends this autumn may have an urgent question for the administration when they arrive on campus: Will tuition and fees keep surging?
 ''The real question is how stiff are they going to be,'' said Travis Reindle, director of state policy analysis at the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. 
 Mary Peloquin-Dodd, the director of the Higher Education Group at Standard & Poor's Corporation, predicted a range of 4 to 6 percent increase for many Connecticut colleges over the next couple of years, with some as high as 8 percent.
 The largest components of college expenses -- teacher and staff salaries and benefits -- are propelled by surging health care costs, she said. Add in increased security needs, higher insurance fees, rapid technology obsolescence, less income from endowment investments in the moribund stock and bond markets, higher utility bills, and sharply lower state and federal funding and the outlook for tamping down expenses is poor. 
 ''If you look at it that way, maybe 4 to 6 percent increases aren't really so bad,'' Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said. Mr. Reindle said signs are pointing to improvement, ''because the economy seems to be stabilizing. We're headed back in the direction of 6 percent, but I don't know if we'll hit that in the next five years. If the economy tanks, all bets are off.'' 
 The rise in tuition and fees this year for in-staters at Connecticut's public universities was 7.7 percent for the University of Connecticut's main campus from $6,812 last year to $7,338, according to the state Department of Higher Education. Last year the jump was 10.7 percent from $6,154 in 2002-3.
 For the four colleges in the Connecticut State University system, tuition and fees this year were up 12.5 percent, from an average $5,121 last year to an average $5,760.
 Connecticut's public institutions' increases in tuition and fee totals bested national figures. Nationally, tuition and fees at four-year public institutions averaged an estimated 10 percent increase, or about $475, to $5,125 from last year's $4,694, Mr. Reindle said. 
 Tuition and fees at Connecticut's private colleges rose 6 percent this year from $22,463 last year to $23,858, according to the Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges.
 Connecticut's numbers for the private schools matched the national averages. Nationally, tuition and fees for this year were up 6 percent from $17,040 for 2003-4 to $18,062, according to the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. 
 With the addition of room and board, a major chunk of the bill, the five private colleges in Connecticut with the highest totals were, in order: 1. Wesleyan University ($40,124 this year, up 5.7 percent from $37,964 in 2003-4); 2. Connecticut College ($39,975, up 5.5 percent from $37,900); 3. Yale University ($38,850, up 5 percent from $37,000); 4. Trinity College ($38,640, up 5.7 percent from $36,550), and 5. Fairfield University ($37,205, up 6.1 percent from $35,055).
 Approximate totals for other Connecticut private colleges include Quinnipiac University in Hamden ($32,400 this year, up 6 percent from $30,570 in 2003-4); St. Joseph College in West Hartford ($30,595 up 5 percent from $29,135); Sacred Heart University in Fairfield ($31,270, up 7.3 percent from $29,130); the University of Bridgeport ($27,850, up 7.7 percent from $25,658); Teikyo Post University in Waterbury ($27,750, up 12 percent from $24,785); Mitchell College in New London ($27,700, up 5 percent from $26,396); the University of New Haven ($27,000, up 5.6 percent from $25,475) and Albertus Magnus College in New Haven ($24,350, up 3.6 percent from $23,498).
 ''Over the last 10 years the average annual increase for private schools has been 5.5 percent, and as cost-drivers continue to increase at the same rate that we've seen over the last several years, it's very likely that tuition increases will also continue to rise by the same approximate rate,'' said Tony Pals, the college association spokesman.
 The constant increases have led Marcia Bromberg, Wesleyan University's longtime finance officer, to ask the same two questions in tuition-setting meetings every March: Is college tuition getting to a point where no one will pay it? Will the parents rebel?
 With tuition and room and board exceeding $40,000 at Wesleyan and many Connecticut colleges eyeing that hurdle, that time may be in sight. Indeed, in a national report card for the 50 states issued Sept. 15, Connecticut got an ''F'' for college affordability. The National Center for Public Policy and Education, in its latest biennial report, found that in-state public four-year colleges cost Connecticut families about 29 percent of their annual income before financial aid. 
 But parents are not balking, Ms. Bromberg said.
 ''When it hit $30,000, everybody said no one will pay it,'' she recalled. ''The reality is people will pay whatever we charge them. There's no end to what people will pay. In fact, the more you charge, the more they like it. People look around and say, 'If they charge a lot, it must be good.''' 
 But some institutions can moderate the inexorable rise in fees better than others, Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said, including the state-supported University of Connecticut and Yale University, with its $11 billion endowment and multiple income sources from research and other endeavors.
 ''Schools that have always had a tremendous demand will probably be fine,'' Ms. Peloquin-Dodd said, ''but the tuition-dependent institutions right in the middle without large endowments will get financially squeezed more and more.'' 
 But some small colleges with not much endowment can keep fee increases modest if they've found a niche. 
 Fairfield University -- a small private Catholic liberal-arts school with 3,200 undergraduates located in a well-to-do Fairfield neighborhood -- has kept its annual increase at about 6 percent over the past five years.
 ''I don't see it changing dramatically in the next couple of years,'' said William Lucas, vice president for finance. Fairfield's income comes from tuition and fees, a modest endowment of $147 million and annual gifts of about $2.5 million.
 But Fairfield faces ever-tougher competition with other Catholic institutions like Providence College, Loyola of Maryland, Villanova, Boston College and Holy Cross. To gain an edge, in the past five years Fairfield poured $100 million into facility upgrades and expansions. There are also now two fields for soccer, lacrosse and field hockey, with an artificial surface for multiple sports and a new natural surface field. 
 Fairfield has not cut courses or staff, giving all full-time workers an extra $500 instead of raises. The college also had a big increase in the number of applications from 5,600 in 1998 for 850 freshman slots to more than 7,000 this year for the same number of slots. 
 The public University of Connecticut is a growing giant, priding itself on its recent extensive building construction and expansion, competitive pricing, huge amount of financial aid, and the increasing number of higher-quality applicants. UConn has 20,259 undergraduates, 80 percent housed on the sprawling Storrs campus and the five other regional campuses, up from 16,681 in fall 2000.
 Next year, UConn has proposed raising tuition, fees, and room and board 5.81 percent from $14,894 to $15,760 while keeping the enrollment the same. The year starting fall 2006, it would hit $16,782, up 6.46 percent. Financial aid totaled $131.8 million in 2000. This year it was $208 million. Next year, the proposal is for $217 million, and $226 million for 2005-2006. Partly as a result, freshman applications grew from 12,642 in 2000 to an estimated 19,500 in 2004.
 ''We are making sure that our doors are open to any smart kid, regardless of financial circumstances,'' said Lorraine Aronson, the chief financial officer. 
 The key to UConn's finances is state support, substantially greater than any other public school in New England. Since the state legislature passed the ''UConn 2000'' program in 1995, providing $1 billion for capital expenses -- new buildings, renovations and equipment -- the university has added three dozen new buildings and renovated four dozen. 
 Last year, the legislature added the 21st-century UConn program, providing $1.3 billion for capital expenses. In return, UConn has been obliged to raise on its own whatever it needs for operating expenses. As a result, fees had to increase. Still, this year, UConn is less expensive than most of its main public competitors, the University of Vermont, Rutgers, the University of New Hampshire, Penn State, the University of Maryland and the University of Rhode Island.
 ''Every indicator is we're shooting the lights out,'' said Dolan Evanovich, UConn's enrollment manager. ''Our position in the marketplace has never been stronger.'' 
 Quinnipiac University in Hamden, with 5,130 undergraduates, up from 4,339 in fall 2000, has a small endowment of $150 million, up substantially from $53 million in 2000. Enrollment growth is a major strategy for keeping fee increases moderate, and finding a niche is the key to adding students, said Joan Isaac Mohr, the dean of admissions.
 ''We are aware of career demands, new career areas as they develop, and we try to be responsive to the marketplace,'' she said.
 Niche programs include physical therapy, occupational therapy, nursing, physician assistant and athletics training. In liberal arts, the focus is on interactive digital design, criminal justice and psychology. The college also specializes in public relations, journalism and TV production. To gain an edge, Quinnipiac installed a fully digital high-definition television production facility.
 College is a marketplace, Ms. Aronson said. 
 ''People are buying a product,'' she said. ''They want high-quality education for their kids, and a low-quality education is no bargain at all.''

HEADLINE: Ford Parks Its Natural Gas Bandwagon

BYLINE: By CHRIS DIXON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
AFTER a decade spent preaching the gospel of clean-burning natural gas and winning converts among air-quality regulators and vehicle fleet operators, Ford is leaving the congregation. 
 The company produced its final natural gas vehicles last month. Once those cars and trucks are delivered to customers, Ford says it will turn its full attention to the development of other types of green cars, including those that would run on hydrogen fuel cells. But existing customers and natural gas proponents say the move will have serious consequences, since Ford was the sole supplier of several types of vehicles.
 Cars and trucks that run on compressed natural gas, or C.N.G., have distinct environmental benefits compared with gasoline or diesel vehicles. The combustion produces fewer greenhouse gases, less soot and lower smog-causing emissions. The differences are so significant that a number of state and local governments, as well as corporations, have added C.N.G. vehicles to their fleets. 
 And in contrast with crude oil, natural gas is a domestic energy source; nearly all of what is consumed in the United States is produced in North America. 
 Before Ford announced its withdrawal from the market, in January, interest in natural gas vehicles had seemed to be growing. Next year, Honda will offer a home-fueling device for its lone natural gas automobile, the Civic GX, which the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy has rated the world's greenest car. Ford of Europe is preparing to put natural gas versions of the Ford Focus and Volvo S40 on the road. And increasingly, municipal buses and garbage trucks are running on natural gas.
 In the United States, Ford has been the leader in natural gas vehicles, having produced nearly 30,000 since 1997. Its models -- including the Crown Victoria sedan, F-150 pickup and Econoline vans -- are used by taxi companies, municipalities, police forces and utilities.
 Thus, Ford's decision to pull out of the market has left many green-fleet vehicle operators and planners in the lurch. It has disappointed natural gas proponents, who say it is environmentally short-sighted and a blow against energy self-sufficiency.
 ''What gets me is that Ford made a lot about being an environmental company,'' said Andrew Littlefair, president of Clean Energy, the leading distributor of natural gas for vehicles. ''Then the same month that they decided to shut down the natural gas vehicle deal, they decided to produce the Excursion for another year.'' The Excursion, the nation's largest mass-market S.U.V., is a particular target of environmentalists.
 Last weekend, at a San Antonio meeting of the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition, a group of equipment manufacturers, suppliers and lobbyists, many of the delegates conceded that there was little chance of persuading Ford to reverse itself. Some held out hope that the automaker might at least certify other companies to convert its vehicles. 
 But David Henry, business strategy manager for Ford's alternative fuel vehicle program, said the automaker was unlikely to license any aftermarket company to do the $5,000 to $8,000 conversions in the near future. He said Ford would continue to cover its own natural gas cars under warranty, but if a car converted by another company had a problem caused by the conversion, that specific repair would not be covered. 
 Ford's decision to stop making natural gas vehicles is ''a huge deal,'' said Mike Eaves, president of the California Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition, adding, ''The taxi market wants a big four-door sedan with rear-wheel drive, and the Crown Victoria is the only one in North America.'' 
 Jim Harger, senior vice president of Clean Energy, noted that Crown Victoria taxis were in use around airports at Los Angeles, Phoenix, Seattle and San Francisco, among others. ''Ford's reluctance to continue the C.N.G. Crown Victoria will negatively impact clean-fleet policies at these airports,'' he said.
 Mr. Henry of Ford said that while the company's natural gas vehicles were profitable, they were not selling well enough to justify the program.
 In addition, he said Ford wanted to shift its engineers and resources to combined gas-electric vehicles like its new Escape Hybrid, to cleaner-burning gasoline technology like its very clean ''partial zero emissions'' Focus and to fuel-cell vehicles.
 ''Although we led the market in C.N.G.,'' Mr. Henry said, ''the total volume compared to our other product lines was very minimal.'' 
 Of the estimated 130,000 natural gas vehicles on American roads, some 20,000 are in California -- including about 5,000 in the hands of individuals -- where they can refuel at more than 200 stations. The vehicles are legal in the state's high-occupancy lanes, even without passengers.
 In New York City, some 6,000 natural gas fleet vehicles, many of them operated by Consolidated Edison or by city agencies, can use about 20 fueling stations. Natural gas is also used in city transit fleets in Atlanta, Washington, Boston, Cleveland and Phoenix, and by many utilities.
 Compared with gasoline, combustion of natural gas in cars produces 70 percent less carbon monoxide and 87 percent less nitrogen oxide. According to the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental advocacy group, the most affordable shuttle vans and school buses are often diesel-fueled. The cleanest of these produce five times the soot and twice the smog-forming compounds of comparable natural-gas vehicles. 
 Diesel combustion also produces some 40 toxic air contaminants, while natural gas combustion is safe enough for heating and cooking in millions of homes. Natural gas vehicles produce about 20 percent less emissions of the greenhouse gases that cause global warming, principally carbon dioxide, than comparable petroleum-fueled vehicles.
 This figure is quite significant, Mr. Harger said, because air resources boards in California, New York and New Jersey are considering whether to require automakers to reduce greenhouse gases by as much as 30 percent in coming decades. Natural gas vehicles could help considerably in meeting such a standard. 
 ''People ask us why we are fooling with this technology,'' said Mr. Littlefair of Clean Energy, ''Well, you have 7,000 C.N.G. trash trucks in Southern California. That's like taking two million vehicles off the road.''
 Compared with gasoline and diesel, natural gas customers pay around 20 percent less per gallon, but the operating cost is comparable because the mileage of C.N.G. vehicles is about 20 percent lower. 
 Automotive C.N.G. tanks have a good safety record, but their smaller capacity generally means that the vehicles cannot travel as far without refueling as a gasoline or diesel car can go. And though natural gas costs less per gallon today, demand is rising even as safety and environmental concerns raise potential hurdles to new wells, import terminals and storage facilities. 
 Ford was one of the first companies to offer natural gas vehicles. In 1984, the automaker delivered 27 modified Ranger pickups to North American utilities. The company invested in fueling infrastructure and expanded to a full line of natural gas cars, light trucks and medium-duty trucks, including a ''bi-fuel'' F-150 pickup that runs on either gasoline or natural gas. The C.N.G. Crown Victoria is the only full-size car powered by natural gas.
 Chrysler produced a few C.N.G. minivans and a shuttle in the early 1990's, and General Motors stepped in with a limited line that included full-size pickups and a van, which has since been discontinued.
 In 1993, Honda introduced its Civic GX, and the bulk of its sales have been to fleet operators, including New York City. Early next year, Honda plans to step up its GX marketing while offering its FuelMaker home-fueling system. By tapping into residential gas lines, FuelMaker can be used with any C.N.G. vehicle, not just Hondas. 
 Until then, refueling typically involves taking the vehicle to a dedicated filling station with high-pressure hoses that attach to special fittings on the vehicle. Fueling is not considered dangerous, but filling stations remain sparse. 
 This is one reason Ford pulled out, Mr. Henry said. ''Despite our best efforts, one of the things that was a real inhibitor was a lack of infrastructure,'' he said. ''It was our customers telling us that it was just too inconvenient, and not knowing where the next fueling point was.''
 Mr. Henry also said that the company had other demands on its resources. ''It's no secret that Ford is going through a revitalization plan,'' he said. ''We had to focus on rebuilding our product lineup.'' 
 Mr. Henry said that if hybrid vehicles sold well, their volume would reduce oil imports by more than a relatively small number of C.N.G. vehicles. He added that while Ford would keep an eye on Honda's fuel-at-home system, the future eventually belongs to hydrogen and fuel cells. 
 Mr. Littlefair said he wondered how that future would arrive if Ford never took further steps away from gasoline cars. ''I think a lot of this is public posturing,'' he said. ''In California, you've got natural gas pipelines running up and down every street. In populated areas, it's everywhere. It's a day at the beach compared with creating an infrastructure with hydrogen.'' 
 Mr. Eaves of the California natural gas coalition expressed frustration that a vehicle technology financed in part through utilities in that state, and thus its customers, was now heading overseas.
 ''The Focus showing up in Europe is kind of a slap in the face of the U.S.,'' he said. ''A lot of California rate payers helped finance Ford's N.G.V. development program. Now they're pulling out and using that expertise somewhere else.''

HEADLINE: Britain Offering to Pay Off 10% of Third World Debt

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
Britain is planning a new effort to help poor countries reduce their huge debts by offering to pay off 10 percent of the total owed to international agencies and challenging other nations to follow suit, said Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer.
 In an address on Sunday to an advocacy group called the Trade Justice Movement, Mr. Brown also plans to repeat an earlier proposal that the International Monetary Fund should revalue its vast gold reserves, currently priced at a tenth of their market value, and use the proceeds to cancel some third world debt, according to a text of his remarks published Saturday in The Guardian and later confirmed by the Treasury.
 The issue is rising once more on the international agenda because a previous mechanism for debt relief, set up in 1996 by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, is to be renewed in December for two years. James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, said Friday in Washington that the White House had devised a plan to cancel some third world debt, Reuters reported. Senator John Kerry, the Democratic presidential challenger, has also promised to lead efforts to cancel the debts of impoverished countries if he is elected. 
 Mr. Brown's proposal is significant because it comes just days before the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington. The finance ministers of the Group of 7 major industrial nations, including Mr. Brown, are also to meet just before those gatherings.
 ''What we hope is that this will break the logjam that has been there for some time,'' said Brendan Cox, a spokesman for Oxfam, a nonprofit group that has urged accelerated moves to cancel third world debt. ''If others follow suit it will be a massive turning point in efforts to end the burden of international debt.''
 Mr. Brown plans to tell the meeting of anti-debt campaigners on Sunday that Britain will set aside the equivalent of $180 million a year to pay off 10 percent of the money owed by 32 countries to international lenders, notably the World Bank and the African Development Bank. Poor nations contend that they often must choose between paying these debts and meeting urgent needs of their people, or making expenditures that would strengthen their economies. 
 ''Because the poor cannot wait, we intend to lead by example by paying our share of their payments to the World Bank and the African Development Bank,'' Mr. Brown is planning to say. ''We do this alone today, but we urge you to use your moral authority to urge other countries to follow suit so that poor countries can look forward to a future free from the shackles of debt.'' 
 Mr. Brown will also argue that the debt owed to the International Monetary Fund could be cut by a revaluation of the fund's gold stocks, currently worth $8.5 billion when valued at $40 per ounce. The market price for gold is now over $400 an ounce.
 ''Because we cannot bury the hopes of half of humanity in the lifeless vaults of gold, the cancellation of debt owed to the I.M.F. should be paid for by the better use of I.M.F. gold,'' Mr. Brown plans to say. His speech will be given as part of the preparations for the annual conference of the governing Labor Party in Brighton, in southern England.
 Hilary Benn, the minister responsible for British overseas aid, said the British move ''throws down a challenge to the rest of the world.'' Some estimates put the total debt owed by the poorest countries at around $200 billion.
 Romilly Greenhill, a spokeswoman for the Action Aid debt relief advocacy group, said the sum of $180 million mentioned by Mr. Brown was apparently part of Britain's annual budget for development, currently totaling about $7 billion. ''It is not strictly new money in the sense that it has already been included in the aid budget,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Don't Worry, Be Happy (Even if Earnings Go Soft)

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM; Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN the long run, the two main drivers of a stock price are the profits the company produces and the amount that investors are willing to pay for them. So whenever investors turn cautious, as they have recently, and price-to-earnings ratios flatten out or fall, attention turns naturally to the other driver: the profits themselves. 
 Until recently, the earnings picture looked amazingly bright, as companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index posted four consecutive quarters of profit growth of more than 20 percent. 
 But the mood has started to shift. The big concern now is that growth in earnings, while still healthy by historical standards, has been decelerating. A majority of American fund managers surveyed this month by Merrill Lynch say they think that profits will ''deteriorate slightly'' in the coming months. And the consensus forecast for third-quarter earnings growth for the S.&P. 500 companies is 14.2 percent, down sharply from the estimated 25.3 percent in the second quarter this year, according to Thomson First Call. 
 Conventional wisdom says that when earnings growth begins to slow, it's time to worry. That is especially the case when investors aren't willing to pay exorbitant P/E ratios for stocks. After all, if both earnings growth and P/E ratios plateau at the same time, what is left to propel equity prices higher? 
 A slowdown in earnings, even if actual profits are growing by double digits, ''is considered to be a warning sign'' of poorer economic and business prospects to come, noted Sung Won Sohn, chief economic officer at Wells Fargo Banks. 
 But while decelerating earnings have proved to be challenging for investors in the past, they do not automatically lead to lower stock prices. ''If you look at the very, very long term, there's clearly a high correlation between growth in earnings and growth in the market,'' said Stuart H. Wester, vice president for equity investments at USAA Investment Management. But as you narrow the time frame, he added, ''you can find yourself in a situation where the two can diverge dramatically.'' 
 Certainly, equity prices have sometimes soared even as corporate earnings have begun to sour. That happened most recently in 1995, when the S.&P. 500 delivered a total return of more than 37 percent despite the start of a slowdown in earnings growth. No one is predicting a repeat of that, but it goes to show that while earnings drive stock prices in the long term, other factors can also influence the markets in the short term.
 Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at S.&P., studied periods of decelerating earnings among S.&P. 500 stocks dating back to 1966. In the six months after the peaks of profit cycles, stocks were up on 4 out of 10 occasions. Twelve months after such peaks, stocks were showing positive returns 6 out of 10 times. 
 But this time around, consider where earnings are decelerating from. Starting with the third quarter of 2003, S.&P. 500 earnings have climbed by more than 20 percent for four consecutive quarters -- something that has happened only seven other times since the end of World War II, according to Ned Davis Research. 
 Ed Clissold, senior global analyst at Ned Davis, recently looked at the performance of the equity markets emerging from those seven periods. He found that in the 12 months after the end of such streaks, the S.&P. 500 has risen 8.3 percent, on average. The median increase was closer to 15.3 percent. 
 The numbers defy the current level of market concern over deceleration. ''The markets in the short term are almost always drunk with too much optimism or pessimism,'' said Alan F. Skrainka, chief market strategist at Edward Jones. He added: ''I'm not overly concerned that the rate of growth has peaked and is about to moderate.''
 But what if the earnings growth rate didn't just moderate, but fell substantially? Even if the third-quarter forecast of 14.2 percent proves way too high, stocks' performance in the next year could still be decent. 
 Ned Davis researchers studied the performance of the markets based on actual earnings growth dating back to 1927. In periods when actual S.&P. 500 earnings growth came in at 5 percent to 20 percent, the markets have gained 5.3 percent, annualized. But when profits were worse -- in a range of 5 percent growth to 20 percent earnings declines -- stocks have actually done better, gaining 13.1 percent, on average. 
 The reason for that outperformance has a lot to do with anticipation. ''By the time earnings growth gets extremely high, a lot of the good news is already priced into the stock market,'' Mr. Clissold said. Similarly, decelerating earnings may already have been priced into this market, as investors have been expecting the trend for months. 
 That isn't to say earnings growth is unimportant. But it tends to matter most when determining the types of stocks to hold, not whether to stay in the stock market at all. 
 ''If you're thinking about rotating, between high-quality and low-quality stocks or growth and value, then you're going to want to pay attention to accelerating or decelerating earnings,'' said Richard Bernstein, chief United States strategist at Merrill Lynch.
 For example, while low-quality and economically sensitive stocks thrived in 2003, in anticipation of the upswing in the profit cycle that began in the third quarter that year, Mr. Bernstein says that now is the time to be moving into higher-quality names with strong balance sheets -- companies strong enough to thrive as profit growth begins to shrink.
 HE recently looked at the last three periods of decelerating earnings growth -- periods of varying durations that began in 1989, 1995 and 2000. From the peaks to the troughs, high-quality stocks -- those rated A+ by S.&P., based on earnings quality -- gained 63 percent, on average, for the three periods. By contrast, stocks graded C or D advanced just 20 percent.
 Investors who fail to recognize the deceleration in earnings may be tempted to keep putting money into yesterday's winners, Mr. Bernstein said. Typically, he said, at the peak of profit cycles, ''people extrapolate the trends and assume that what did well yesterday will continue to do well today.'' But history shows that this could be a big mistake -- just as it would be to assume that the broad stock market will automatically fall, now that earnings growth is slowing.
